stem: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of weakness and arthralgias for the last four months. He also has a pruritic rash on his legs that appeared two months ago. He denies fever or chills and his weight has been stable. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 84/min. A rash is present on both lower extremities below the knees that consist of many erythematous macules. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count: Hematocrit 34%, Platelets 140,000~cells/mu L, Leukocyte count 3,000~cells/mu L. Serum chemistry: Creatinine 1.7~mg/dL, Albumin 3.1~g/dL, Aspartate aminotransferase 78 U/L, Alanine aminotransferase 99~U/L. Urinalysis: Protein +3, Blood moderate, Red blood cells 20-30/hpf. Immunologic studies: Complement C3 50~mg/dL, C4 10~mg/dL (12-75 mg/dL), Rheumatoid factor 90~U/mL (< 40 U/mL), HIV antibody negative. Which of the following would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with mixed cryoglobulinemia causing glomerulonephritis. Cryoglobulinemia is classified as either type I or mixed (types II and III). Diagnosis is suggested by elevated cryoglobulins (cryocrit), ESR, CRP, autoantibodies (e.g., RF, ANA), and clinical symptoms. Mixed cryoglobulinemia is commonly associated with hepatitis C and elevated liver function tests, and more than 60% of patients with hepatitis C have cryoglobulins. Approximately 20% of patients with cryoglobulinemia develop renal disease, which is usually glomerulonephritis from hepatitis C-containing immune complexes. Patients with hepatitis C-associated cryoglobulinemia have a higher risk of developing lymphoma up to 5-10 years later. Treatment involves eradicating HCV, immunosuppression (eg, prednisone, cyclophosphamide), and/or plasmapheresis for moderate-severe cryoglobulinemia. (Choice A) Anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) can also cause anemia, thrombocytopenia, livedo reticularis, and glomerulonephritis. However, this patient has increased AST and ALT and low albumin, suggesting chronic liver disease. Also, most patients with APS have thrombotic episodes (eg. DVT. strokes). (Choice B) Bone marrow biopsy is more useful in type I cryoglobulinemia to diagnose an underlying hematological condition with bone marrow involvement. (Choice C) Serum protein electrophoresis can help diagnose underlying plasma cell disorders (eg. multiple myeloma or Waldenström's macroglobulinemia), but they are associated more with type I than mixed cryoglobulinemia. (Choice D) Heroin users can develop membranous nephropathy (due to hepatitis B), membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (due to hepatitis C), or focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with vasculitis. Viral serologies are more likely to give a correct diagnosis in this patient given the low white cell count, thrombocytopenia, and increased AST/ALT. Educational objective: Mixed cryoglobulinemia is commonly associated with hepatitis C and can cause glomerulonephritis. Treatment includes eradicating hepatitis C and immunosuppression and/or plasmapheresis for cryoglobulinemia.

stem: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of crampy lower abdominal pain and diarrhea that awakens him at night. He says he might have some blood in his stool, but he is not sure. He also complains of fatigue. His past medical history is unremarkable. He takes a daily multivitamin and exercises regularly. He has a stable male partner and uses condoms regularly. His mother died of lymphoma and his older brother suffers from ulcerative colitis. He is afebrile. His blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 12/min. His bowel sounds are normoactive. There is mild abdominal tenderness in both lower quadrants without rebound tenderness. His examination is otherwise unremarkable. The patient's labs reveal: Complete blood count: Hematocrit 24%, MCV 87 fl, Platelets 55,000~cells/mu L, Leukocyte count 11,000~cells/mu L. Serum chemistry panel: Sodium 140~mEq/L, Potassium 4.4~mEq/L, Chloride 102~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 22~mEq/L, Creatinine 2.4~mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury after a recent diarrheal illness) is concerning for hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), most commonly caused by a shiga toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic E. coli. HUS is more common in children (but can also be seen in adults) and is similar to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is more commonly seen in adults. However, HUS is associated with more renal disease and fewer primary neurological symptoms than TTP. The diagnosis of HUS is made clinically in patients who present with the classic triad after a prodromal diarrheal illness. As a result, a peripheral blood smear should be done next to look for schistocytes (fragmented blood cells), indicating a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. (Choice A) Antimotility drugs (anticholinergics and narcotics) do not decrease the gastrointestinal symptoms, but can worsen HUS by increasing the risk of central nervous system dysfunction. As a result, antimotility agents are not recommended for a patient with suspected HUS from enterohemorrhagic E. coli. (Choice C) Empiric antibiotics do not decrease the duration of gastrointestinal symptoms and can possibly worsen HUS by increasing shiga toxin release. (Choice D) Sigmoidoscopy is indicated to evaluate for colitis, which can sometimes mimic HUS. However, the thrombocytopenia and renal injury are usually not seen in colitis and makes it less likely in this patient. (Choice E) Stool cultures are not as sensitive to detect enterohemorrhagic E. coli, since the bacteria may only be present in the stool for a few days after the onset of the illness. Serologic testing for E. coli is more sensitive. Educational objective: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome is associated with a prodromal diarrheal illness, usually caused by a shiga toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic E. coli leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. The diagnosis is made clinically and can be evaluated with peripheral blood smear to look for schistocytes as well as serologic testing for enterohemorrhagic E. coli.

stem: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office because of frequent urination. She urinates approximately every 30 to 60 minutes during the day, which makes it difficult to concentrate at work and attend meetings. She also gets up 1 to 2 times per night to urinate. The patient drinks "a lot of fluid to stay caught up." She says that her 'migraines' have worsened recently and she occasionally feels nauseated. She got a new pair of glasses due to worsening of her vision, which she attributes to spending a lot of time at work. She has had no lower abdominal pain or dysuria. Her other medical problems include anxiety disorder and knee trauma that she sustained three months ago while jogging. She required arthroscopic surgery and took opioid medications for pain control for two weeks. She has not experienced any knee pain since. Her BMI is 18~kg/m^{2} Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum chemistry: Sodium 136 mEq/L, Potassium 3.8 mEq/L, Chloride 104 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, Glucose 80 mg/dL. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.010, PH 5.6, Protein none, Blood negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells 1-2/hpf. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Eight hours following a water deprivation, her weight remains unchanged and her plasma and urine osmolalties are 284 and 650~mosm/kg $H{2}O$ respectively. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient presents with polyuria with dilute urine and increased water intake, which is usually due to diabetes insipidus (DI) or primary polydipsia. However, the polyuria with water loss is appropriate in polydipsia but inappropriate in DI. Serum Na > 145 mEq/L with a urine osmolality < serum osmolality excludes primary polydipsia and suggests DI. However, patients with an intact thirst mechanism will have adequate water intake to compensate for the water loss and may have a normal sodium level (as in this patient). In cases where a clinical diagnosis is difficult, a water deprivation test should be done to confirm the diagnosis. However, patients suspected of having nephrogenic DI should receive desmopressin without water deprivation and be monitored for a lack of response. This patient is able to concentrate her urine and preserve her plasma osmolality at a normal level in response to observed water deprivation. This suggests that antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release and action are both intact and that the cause of her polyuria is excess fluid intake (primary polydipsia). Her urinary concentration may be subnormal due to chronic water diuresis. (Choice A) Amphetamine abuse can lead to hyponatremia due to increased fluid intake (from hyperthermia) and persistent secretion of ADH that decreases water excretion. This patient's water deprivation test is more consistent with primary polydipsia. (Choice B) Central diabetes insipidus would be associated with weight loss, increasing plasma osmolality (due to renal water loss), and urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg in response to water deprivation. (Choice C) Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus would not be associated with an increase in urine osmolality to this level with water deprivation. (Choice E) Chronic diuretic use/abuse is usually associated with hypokalemic alkalosis, which is not present in this patient. Educational objective: Polyuria and polydipsia can be due either to a solute diuresis (usually uncontrolled diabetes mellitus with glycosuria) or a water diuresis. Water diuresis can be due to impaired ADH secretion (central DI), impaired action of ADH on the kidney (nephrogenic DI), or excess fluid intake. The response to controlled/observed water deprivation differentiates among these possibilities.

stem: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to shortness of breath. His symptoms began when he woke up today and have not diminished since. The patient also reports mild chest pressure but has no cough, fever, wheezing, or chest pain. He was diagnosed with idiopathic membranous nephropathy 6 months ago during evaluation of anasarca, and cyclophosphamide and prednisone therapy were begun due to persistent heavy proteinuria. The patient is a lifelong nonsmoker and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (99.0 F), blood pressure is 144/84 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min. Oxygen saturation is 91% while breathing ambient air. There is no jugular venous distension. The lungs are clear on auscultation, and cardiac examination shows no abnormalities with the exception of tachycardia. The patient has 2+ bilateral, lower extremity pitting edema. There is no calf tenderness. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 38%, Platelets 200,000/mm^{3}, Creatinine 1.8~mg/dL, Calcium 8.8~mg/dL, Albumin 2.0~g/dL, Troponin I 0.3~ng/mL (normal: <0.012~ng/mL), B-type natriuretic peptide 233~pg/mL (normal <100~pg/mL). Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.015, Protein 3+, Blood Negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells 5-10/hpf, Casts Occasional granular. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this patient's current symptoms?
choice_b: Occlusion of the right coronary artery
explanation: This patient with membranous nephropathy (a nephrotic syndrome) and acute-onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia likely has a pulmonary embolism (PE) In patients with nephrotic syndrome, PE is often the presenting manifestation of chronic renal venous thrombosis ( (RVT). Patients with nephrotic syndrome (urine protein >3.5 g/day, albumin <3~g/dL edema) have a markedly increased risk of (venous > arterial) thrombosis, with 12\%-30\% of patients developing PE. The hypercoagulable state is likely due to both urinary loss of antithrombin III and plasminogen and increased levels of fibrinogen with platelet activation. Membranous nephropathy, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome, carries the highest risk of thrombosis; up to 60% of patients with membranous nephropathy will develop RVT. This risk is particularly high in patients with >1k g/day of urinary protein or <2 g/dL of serum albumin. RVT that develops in membranous nephropathy is typically chronic, asymptomatic, and often not associated with worsening renal function or proteinuria (as opposed to acute RVT, which presents with pain, hematuria, and renal failure). The thrombus can propagate into the inferior vena cava and embolize into the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in PE (often the only manifestation of chronic RVT). Diagnosis of RVT can be made by selective venography, Doppler ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI; however, routine screening in membranous nephropathy is not recommended. Treatment is anticoagulation. (Choice A) Cyclophosphamide pulmonary toxicity typically results in a pneumonitis with symptoms of cough, fatigue, and dyspnea. It would be unlikely to cause acute chest pain, tachycardia, and a troponin elevation. (Choice B) Right coronary artery myocardial infarction causes an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn causes chest pain and dyspnea; however, an ECG would show ST elevations in the inferior leads (II,III, and aVF). If the right ventricle is involved, hypotension and elevated jugular venous pressure will predominate. The troponin elevation is likely due to right heart strain from acute PE. (Choice C) Pericardial effusions can cause shortness of breath and tachycardia; however, patients typically have elevated jugular venous distension, hypotension, and low voltages on ECG. (Choice D) Bilateral renal artery stenosis can cause flash pulmonary edema (Pickering syndrome); however, this typically presents with hypoxia, severe hypertension, and jugular venous distension. Educational objective: Nephrotic syndrome, particularly membranous nephropathy, is associated with a high frequency of thromboembolic events, predominately deep venous and renal venous thrombosis. Renal venous thrombosis is often asymptomatic; pulmonary embolism may be the presenting sign.

stem: A 40-year-old man with end-stage renal disease comes to the office for routine follow-up. He has been on chronic hemodialysis for the last 3 years. The patient's parathyroid hormone and alkaline phosphatase levels have increased progressively despite efforts to maintain normal serum phosphorus with phosphate binders and oral vitamin D. Laboratory results are as follows: Creatinine 4.8 mg/dL, Calcium 9.6 mg/dL, Albumin 3.4~g/dL, Alkaline phosphatase 320~U/L, Phosphorus, inorganic, serum 5.1 mg/dL, Parathyroid hormone, serum 700 pg/mL, Vitamin D (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) 60 ng/mL. Adding cinacalcet to this patient's regimen would most likely contribute to which of the following?
explanation: Untreated or inadequately treated hyperphosphatemia and hypocalcemia in chronic kidney disease lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Calcimimetics increase the calcium sensitivity of calcium-sensing receptors on parathyroid glands and reduce serum PTH, calcium, and phosphate levels. Cinacalcet (Sensipar®) reduces fracture risk and improves symptoms of secondary hyperparathyroidism (eg, pruritus, bone pain, fractures, calciphylaxis, and avascular necrosis). Cinacalcet decreases the need for parathyroidectomy by approximately 50%. However, calcimimetics should not be used in patients with hypocalcemia as they may cause seizures and prolong the QT interval. (Choices B and D) Cinacalcet has been shown to reduce cardiovascular risk in patients age >65 but not in younger individuals. (Choice C) Cinacalcet decreases bone turnover due to secondary hyperparathyroidism and therefore reduces the risk for osteitis fibrosa development. (Choice E) The major side effects of cinacalcet are hypocalcemia and gastrointestinal disturbances. Educational objective: Calcimimetics such as cinacalcet decrease the frequency of fractures and the rate of parathyroidectomy in patients with chronic kidney disease who have hyperphosphatemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism. Calcimimetics also reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in older patients (age >65). Major side effects are hypocalcemia and gastrointestinal disturbances.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of bloody urine. This morning, he noticed gross hematuria with passage of a few small blood clots in his urine. He also reports mild dysuria. He has since continued to have grossly bloody urine with occasional small blood clots. He denies fever, chills, back/flank pain, and bruising or bleeding at other sites. He denies any history of urolithiasis or trauma. His other medical problems include a history of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) diagnosed 3 years ago. At that time, he was treated with 6 months of oral cyclophosphamide and tapering doses of prednisone. He has subsequently been maintained on oral methotrexate. He denies recent weight loss, arthralgias, or respiratory symptoms. His blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 16/min. He is afebrile. There are no bruises or petechiae. He does not have any flank pain. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. After sending a urine sample to the laboratory for culture, the following laboratory results are obtained: Hematocrit 34%, Platelets 180,000~cells/mu L, Leukocyte count 7,600~cells/mu L, Serum chemistry Creatinine 1.7~mg/dL (unchanged from previous values), International Normalized Ratio (INR) 1.0, Activated partial thromboplastin time 23 sec, Urinalysis Specific gravity 1.013, Protein +1, Blood gross. Which of the following would have the highest diagnostic yield?
choice_d: Phase contrast microscopy of urine red blood cell morphology
explanation: When hematuria is of renal glomerular or tubular/interstitial origin, a relatively small amount of blood is diluted by tubular fluid and urine. Also, tissue plasminogen and urokinase are present within the tubules and glomeruli. Consequently, glomerular and other intrarenal causes of hematuria are rarely, if ever, associated with the passage of clots into the urine. This patient has a history of cyclophosphamide exposure and presents with painless hematuria in the absence of urinary tract symptoms. Evaluation for bladder lesions via cystoscopy would have the highest diagnostic yield. Cyclophosphamide can induce a chemical cystitis and be associated with the development of bladder cancer. (Choice A) An abdominal CT to look for a renal tumor or stones is appropriate; however, given this patient's history, cystoscopy is of higher diagnostic yield. (Choice B and E) Measurement of ANCA, C-reactive protein, and ESR may help ascertain the activity of this patient's granulomatosis with polyangiitis. A renal biopsy can diagnose and classify kidney involvement in granulomatosis with polyangiitis. However, this patient has a non-glomerular source for his hematuria and cystoscopy is the diagnostic test of choice. (Choice D) The detection of dysmorphic red blood cells (cells with blebs or protrusions, so-called "Mickey-Mouse" head RBCs) in the urine is highly suggestive of a glomerular source of hematuria, as is the presence of RBC casts and >500~mg/day of proteinuria. In this patient, the passage of urinary clots strongly suggests the presence of an extra-glomerular site of bleeding, and cystoscopy should be performed even if dysmorphic urinary RBCs are present. Educational objective: In patients with hematuria, the passage of blood clots in the urine indicates a non-glomerular source of urinary tract bleeding. Thus, evaluation should proceed accordingly.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of bilateral leg swelling. The patient has had 3 months of swelling of the feet and ankles, which has progressively worsened to involve the legs, arms, and lower back. He also noticed shortness of breath 3 months ago while walking a few blocks, and his dyspnea now occurs after walking only a single block. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, mild peripheral neuropathy, and hypertension. His medications include metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. There is no retinopathy. The patient has distended jugular neck veins to the angle of the jaw. Cardiac examination shows an S4 without murmurs. Pulmonary examination reveals bibasilar crackles but otherwise is clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly without splenomegaly. He has 4+ pitting edema to the mid-thigh bilaterally. Laboratory and ECG results are as follows: Creatinine 1.7~mg/dL, Glucose 120~mg/dL, Albumin 2.2~g/dL, Total cholesterol 320~mg/dL, Hemoglobin A1c 6.5%, Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.013, Protein 4+, Blood negative, Glucose negative, Leukocyte esterase negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells (RBCs) 1-2/hpf, RBC casts none, HIV-1 antibody negative, HIV-2 antibody negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's heavy proteinuria, peripheral edema, and low albumin suggest nephrotic syndrome (NS). Common etiologies of adult NS include minimal change disease, lupus, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, membranous nephropathy, and amyloidosis. This patient's clinical findings of heart failure and low-voltage QRS complexes suggest restrictive cardiomyopathy. The combination of restrictive cardiomyopathy and NS is consistent with amyloidosis, which causes up to 20% of NS in patients age >60. Amyloidosis is characterized by extracellular fibrillar deposition of low molecular weight proteins. Amyloid light-chain (AL, or primary) amyloidosis is due to deposition of monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains and can be associated with other plasma cell dyscrasias (eg, multiple myeloma). Amyloid A (AA, or secondary) amyloidosis is usually due to elevated serum amyloid A, which is associated with chronic inflammatory conditions (eg, rheumatoid arthritis). Systemic features (eg, fatigue, weight loss) are more common in AL amyloidosis, though both types can involve multiple organs (Table). Diagnosis can be suggested by detection of a monoclonal protein in serum or urine and is confirmed by positive Congo red stain on tissue biopsy. Treatment (in addition to managing the underlying condition) is largely supportive with <1 year median survival in cardiac amyloidosis. (Choice A) Diabetes can cause peripheral neuropathy and restrictive cardiac disease. However, there is usually a correlation between neuropathy and A1c level (this patient's A1c is not significantly elevated at 6.5%), and patients with diabetic nephropathy also tend to have concurrent retinopathy, which is absent in this patient. (Choices B and C) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and idiopathic membranous nephropathy can cause nephrotic range proteinuria, as seen in this patient. However, neither condition is usually associated with neuropathy or restrictive cardiomyopathy. (Choice D) IgA nephropathy typically presents with significant proteinuria, hematuria, dysmorphic red blood cells, and possibly red blood cell casts on urinalysis. This patient's bland urinary sediment makes this less likely. Educational objective: Amyloidosis (primary IAL] or secondary [AA]) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in patients age >60. Other common manifestations include restrictive cardiomyopathy with heart failure. Treatment is largely supportive.

stem: An 18-year-old man comes to the office because a college physical urinalysis indicated that he had proteinuria. The patient does not recall having a previous urinalysis. He denies flank pain, hematuria, dysuria, nocturia, edema, urinary frequency, hypertension, or family history of kidney disease. His review of systems provides no significant information. He is in excellent health, with the exception of one or two upper respiratory infections per year. He takes no medications. He has no known drug allergies. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs and rarely drinks alcohol. He has no history of a sexually transmitted disease and he is not sexually active. His blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 64/min, and respirations are 12/min. On examination, he appears healthy. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. He has no edema. The patient's laboratory studies reveal: Hematocrit 44%, Platelet count 245,000/mm^{3}, Leukocyte count 8,100/mm^{3}. Serum chemistry: Serum sodium 140~mEq/L, Serum potassium 4.2~mEq/L, Chloride 102~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24~mEq/L, Serum creatinine 0.8~mg/dL. Urine: Specific gravity 1.020, Protein 2+, Blood negative, Glucose negative, Ketones negative, Leukocyte esterase negative, Nitrites negative, WBC 1-2/hpf, RBC 1-2/hpf, Casts none. 24-hour urine: Protein 2,100~mg/24 h, Calculated creatinine clearance 121~mL/min. Blood, plasma Protein: Total 7.0~g/dL, Albumin 4.2~g/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
choice_d: Spot urine protein/creatinine ratio upon arising and at the end of the day
explanation: This patient presents with isolated proteinuria, defined as proteinuria without hematuria or elevated serum creatinine. His unremarkable history, normal estimated glomerular filtration rate, normal blood pressure, and normal urinalysis collectively suggest the absence of significant kidney disease. Orthostatic proteinuria is a condition seen in children, adolescents, and young adults under the age of 30. It is characterized by significant proteinuria in the upright position, but minimal to no proteinuria in the supine position. Long-term follow-up of individuals with this condition has shown resolution of the proteinuria with advancing age in most patients, without development of renal failure. A spot urine sample for protein and creatinine provides a reasonable assessment of quantitative proteinuria, and should be collected during the first morning void and then later in the day in the upright position. Demonstration of little to no proteinuria in the supine position compared to significant proteinuria in the upright position supports the diagnosis. (Choice A) While HIV nephropathy can present as proteinuria, this patient appears to be at low risk for HIV and does not have evidence of kidney disease. (Choice B) In the absence of evidence of active renal disease, a renal biopsy is not indicated. (Choice C) Because this patient has normal renal function and no genitourinary tract symptoms, there is no clear indication for kidney imaging. (Choice E) Electrophoresis of urinary proteins can provide information on the molecular size of proteins in the urine. However, this is not indicated in this patient without evidence of active kidney disease or a systemic disorder. Educational objective: Orthostatic proteinuria is a benign condition commonly seen in children and young adults (2-5%). It is generally less than 1 g/day, but may surpass 3 g/day in select patients. The diagnosis can be established by finding a difference in quantitative proteinuria estimated by spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio obtained upon arising (little, if any, proteinuria) and at the end of the day before recumbency (significant proteinuria).

stem: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up of chronic kidney disease. He feels well overall and has no acute problems. His medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obesity, and hyperlipidemia. His medications include furosemide, simvastatin, low-dose aspirin, amlodipine, and glipizide. Physical examination is normal with +2 peripheral pulses in all extremities. Laboratory results are as follows: Sodium 136 mEq/L, Potassium 4.4~mEq/L, Chloride 102 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 22~mEq/L, Creatinine 3.0~mg/dL, Calcium 8.0~mg/dL, Glucose 120~mg/dL, Albumin 3.7~g/dL, Phosphorus, inorganic 6.0~mg/dL, Parathyroid hormone 200~pg/mL. In addition to a phosphate-restricted diet, which of the following would be the preferred therapeutic option?
explanation: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with hyperphosphatemia due to impaired ability of the kidneys to excrete phosphorus. Hyperphosphatemia is thought to be the inciting event in the onset of CKD-related mineral bone disease (MBD) (osteitis fibrosa, osteomalacia, and adynamic bone disease). Elevated serum phosphate triggers the release of fibroblast growth factor-23 from bone, which lowers calcitriol production and intestinal calcium absorption. Reduced serum calcium, along with hyperphosphatemia, leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Early dietary phosphorus restriction is recommended in all individuals with CKD. Phosphate $(PO{4})$ binders are usually needed as dietary restriction is not sufficient to lower $PO{4}$ levels. $PO{4}$ binders can be calcium containing (calcium carbonate/acetate) or non-calcium containing (sevelamer and lanthanum). Both are equally effective in treating hyperphosphatemia, although calcium-containing binders may be better tolerated. Calcium-containing binders are used in hypocalcemic patients and are also preferred in normocalcemic patients due to cost issues. (Choice A) This patient has normal serum calcium, and vitamin D therapy may further increase serum calcium and promote vascular calcification. (Choice B) Aluminum hydroxide is a potent phosphorus-binding agent, but chronic absorption and accumulation may lead to adynamic bone disease and nonreversible encephalopathy. It should be avoided in CKD patients. (Choices D and E) Excess serum calcium can promote coronary arterial calcification. Non-calcium-containing binders are preferred in patients with hypercalcemia or evidence of vascular calcification. Calcium supplementation in patients with suppressed parathyroid hormone or suspected adynamic bone disease can worsen CKD-MBD. Therefore, sevelamer or lanthanum is also preferred in these patients. Educational objective: Hyperphosphatemia is the inciting event for chronic kidney disease-related mineral bone disease (osteitis fibrosa, osteomalacia, adynamic bone disease). Calcium-containing phosphate binders are preferred in hypocalcemic and normocalcemic patients. Non-calcium-containing binders are used in patients with hypercalcemia, low parathyroid hormone levels, vascular calcification, or suspected adynamic bone disease.

stem: A 64-year-old man comes to the office due to frequent urination. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia with mild hesitancy and occasional nocturia. During the past 8 weeks, he has been bothered by 2 or 3 episodes of nocturia each night and increased urinary urgency. The patient has no dysuria or hematuria and says that his daytime urinary frequency is unchanged. He also has shortness of breath with exertion. His medical history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40% on an echocardiogram a year ago. The patient's medications include furosemide, carvedilol, lisinopril, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulmonary examination reveals bilateral basal crackles. Rectal examination shows a diffusely enlarged prostate. He has 2+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities. Serum sodium is 133~mEq/L, potassium is 3.9~mEq/L, and creatinine is 1.1~mg/dL. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) has worsening nocturia without increase in daytime urinary frequency. He also has signs of fluid retention suggesting worsening heart failure (HF). Patients with congestive HF have decreased renal plasma flow and increased filtration fraction during ambulation. These are associated with sodium retention. Nighttime recumbency improves renal perfusion and sodium excretion, resulting in nocturia. Uncontrolled congestive HF (volume overload) or conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (increased intra-abdominal pressure from coughing and downward displacement of the diaphragm) can worsen symptoms of BPH. The first step in management is to optimize volume status by increasing the dose of diuretics. (Choices B and C) If symptoms of BPH persist in the absence of other inciting factors and after instituting behavioral interventions, an alpha-1-adrenergic antagonist and, if necessary, a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor should be started. (Choice D) Anticholinergic agents such as tolterodine or oxybutynin may be used in BPH with significant irritative symptoms (eg, urgency, incontinence) but should not be started until the patient is euvolemic. (Choice E) Beta blockers should be continued in patients with mild CHF exacerbations without signs of hypotension; discontinuing beta blockers during mild exacerbations has been associated with increased mortality. Educational objective: Decompensated heart failure can worsen symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Volume overload should be treated with increased diuretic doses before adjustments are made to the BPH regimen.

stem: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office due to a rash. She has experienced recurring "red spots" on her legs for 2-3 years. These appear sporadically, last a few weeks to a few months, and disappear spontaneously. The rash is not pruritic. When it occurs, the patient also experiences generalized fatigue and arthralgias involving her hips and knees. She rarely has right lower quadrant pain with the rash. Review of systems is otherwise normal. Medical history is unremarkable. The patient has no known drug allergies. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive, which she has taken for several years. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She is single and works in an office. On examination, the patient appears healthy. Blood pressure is 136/86 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 24~kg/m^{2}. Physical examination is normal except for the skin. A total of 10-12 palpable red lesions, measuring 1	imes0.5 cm, are scattered over both lower extremities distal to the mid-calf. The lesions are nontender and do not blanch with pressure. Laboratory results are as follows: Leukocytes 8,000/mm^{3}, Hematocrit 38%, Platelets 240,000/mm^{3}, Creatinine 1.4~mg/dL. Urine: Specific gravity 1.020, Blood trace, Protein 2+, Glucose negative, Ketones negative, Leukocyte esterase negative, Nitrites negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells 10-20/hpf, Casts occasional red blood cell cast. Which of the following would most likely be found in this patient?
choice_d: Capillary IgA deposits on skin biopsy
choice_e: Focal glomerular sclerosis on renal biopsy
explanation: This patient likely has Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP); although often thought to be a childhood disorder, HSP and its recurrent forms are also seen in adults. It classically presents with the tetrad of palpable purpura (multiple raised, erythematous, nonblanching lesions on the lower extremities), abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement in the form of glomerulonephritis; however, many patients do not have the full tetrad. The disease is a leukocytoclastic vasculitis characterized on skin biopsy by prominent IgA-immune complex deposition in small vessels. IgA deposits also affect the mesangium, resulting in a wide spectrum of renal dysfunction ranging from asymptomatic hematuria to nephrotic syndrome with acute kidney injury. Adults are much more likely than children to experience progressive renal decline. Treatment is mainly supportive; however, glucocorticoids are used in patients with severe renal disease (eg, >750~mg/day of proteinuria, nephrotic syndrome). (Choice A) Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus. Although this condition often involves the joints and kidneys, it is typically associated with a malar or discoid rash (eg, scarring erythematous plaque with scale) rather than palpable purpura. (Choice B) Mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome is associated with hepatitis C infection in up to 95% of cases. The vasculitis presents like that of HSP, with palpable purpura, renal disease, and arthralgias; however, peripheral neuropathy is often present, and abdominal pain is less common and typically less prominent. In addition, hepatitis C infection is unlikely in this patient who was born after 1965 and has no intravenous drug use or blood transfusion history. (Choice C) Anti-Ro antibodies commonly occur in Sjögren syndrome, which is rarely associated with palpable purpura. However, these patients characteristically have sicca symptoms (dry eyes and mouth. parotid gland enlargement), and abdominal pain and renal dysfunction are not typical. (Choice E) Kidney biopsy in HSP usually demonstrates mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis with prominent deposition of IgA. Focal glomerular sclerosis can occur in many contexts (eg, HIV, lupus nephritis, heroin use) but is less common in HSP. Educational objective: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic vasculitis characterized by IgA-immune complex deposition in small vessels and the renal mesangium. It is most common in children but can present in adults and should be suspected in patients with some combination of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal dysfunction.

stem: A 70-year-old man seeks advice for continuing bladder problems. Over the last several years, the patient has had a slow decrease in the volume and force of his urinary stream associated with nocturia and urinary frequency. When seen in the office 12 months ago, his American Urological Association symptom score was 18 (indicating significant symptoms). Digital rectal examination showed a slightly enlarged, smooth, nontender prostate. Urinalysis and prostate-specific antigen were normal. The patient was prescribed a long-acting alpha adrenergic blocker and his symptoms improved. However, he now has intermittent urinary incontinence associated with a strong urge to void. This usually occurs when he senses a full bladder, but it is also triggered by the sound of running water or with exposure to cold. Limiting his fluid intake and scheduling himself to void frequently have not helped. The patient has had no associated dysuria and has not added any new medications in the past year. Genitourinary examination including prostate examination is unchanged from a year ago. Urinalysis is normal. Ultrasound bladder scan estimates a residual urine volume of 60 mL. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's urinary symptoms?
choice_c: Change to another alpha-adrenergic blocking agent
explanation: This patient has benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and initially had typical obstructive voiding symptoms (eg, nocturia, decreased force of stream). However, he has developed urge incontinence, which is caused by detrusor hyperactivity leading to involuntary urine leakage associated with a sudden urge to void. The causes of detrusor hyperactivity are not always apparent, although it frequently occurs in the setting of neurologic disorders and urinary tract infections. Initial management of urge incontinence should include behavioral modification (eg, bladder training, fluid management strategies). Some men with urge incontinence in the setting of BPH may see improvement with alpha-adrenergic antagonist therapy (eg, terazosin, tamsulosin). Persistent symptoms often respond to antimuscarinic agents (eg, tolterodine, oxybutynin). Low-dose antimuscarinic drugs have been shown to be safe and effective for urge incontinence in men with underlying BPH; however, postvoid residual volume (PVR) should be measured prior to initiating therapy. Antimuscarinic agents should be used with caution to avoid causing urine retention in patients with PVR >200 mL. Common side effects include dizziness, dry mouth, and constipation. (Choice A) 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (eg, finasteride) improve lower urinary tract symptoms in men with BPH and large prostate volumes. However, these agents require several weeks to work and are not effective in men without large prostate volumes, such as this patient. (Choice C) It is unlikely that switching to another alpha-adrenergic blocking agent would improve this patient's urge incontinence symptoms. (Choice D) Sacral nerve stimulation via surgical lead placement is the most common and effective long-term surgical intervention for urge incontinence, but it is reserved for patients who fail combined medical therapy. (Choice E) Urodynamic studies provide information on bladder sensation, capacity, detrusor activity, outlet obstruction, and urine flow. However, these tests are invasive and are reserved for evaluation of individuals with unclear or possible multifactorial etiology. Educational objective: Urge incontinence in the setting of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) often responds to alpha-adrenergic blockers. Antimuscarinic agents can be added for patients with persistent symptoms, but postvoid residual volume should be measured before initiating these medications in men with BPH.

stem: A 40-year-old man seeks evaluation for edema. Two days ago, he had sudden onset of swelling in his legs. There was no associated warmth, redness, or tenderness. The patient had a mild cold a week ago and was taking over-the-counter cold remedies. He thought the swelling was an allergic reaction that would go away, but it has not. His past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He takes no prescription or over-the-counter medications. There is no family history of kidney disease. The patient's temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 78/min. He has 3+ pitting edema to the mid-thigh bilaterally. Otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count: Hematocrit 42%, Leukocytes 6,900/mm^{3}. Serum chemistry panel: Sodium 140 mEq/L, Potassium 3.8~mEq/L, Chloride 102~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 26~mEq/L, Blood glucose 100~mg/dL, Albumin 1.9~g/dL, Total cholesterol 420~mg/dL. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.015, pH 5.5, Protein 4+, Blood Negative, Glucose Negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells 1-2/hpf, Casts None, Crystals None. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely to be made with renal biopsy?
explanation: This patient has explosive-onset nephrotic syndrome (edema, 4+ proteinuria, low albumin, elevated cholesterol) occurring shortly after an upper respiratory infection and characterized by lack of red cells or casts on urinalysis, well-maintained glomerular filtration rate, and normal blood pressure. Taken together, these findings are most consistent with minimal change or nil (nothing in light microscopy) disease. Minimal change disease accounts for a large percentage (70%-90%) of childhood and 10%-15% of adult non-diabetic nephrotic syndromes, but the cause remains unknown in the majority of cases. Sudden-onset nephrotic syndrome (as opposed to more progressive proteinuria seen with other forms of nephrotic syndrome) and occurrence after an upper respiratory or systemic infection are typical, some (but not most) patients will have acute kidney injury and hypertension. Renal biopsy usually shows normal-appearing glomeruli on light microscopy and no immune deposits by immunofluorescence. Electron microscopy usually shows effacement of the podocyte foot processes. Adults with new-onset nephrotic syndrome should undergo a renal biopsy to confirm diagnosis, guide therapy, and determine prognosis. Treatment of minimal change disease typically involves corticosteroids. (Choice A) Patients with allergic interstitial nephritis usually do not have proteinuria or nephrotic syndrome. The triad of fever, rash, and eosinophilia due to drug reaction (most frequently nonsteroidal inflammatory drugs, penicillins, or other antibiotics) is classic though not commonly seen. (Choice B) Almost all patients with IgA nephropathy have hematuria (either microscopic or macroscopic), sometimes following upper respiratory tract infection ("synpharyngitic hematuria"). (Choice C) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is usually associated with hematuria and red blood cell casts on urinalysis. These features are not present in this patient. (Choice E) Postinfectious glomerulonephritis often presents with edema, hematuria, leukocyturia, and hypertension, typically 2 weeks after skin or respiratory tract infection in adults. This patient's urine sediment shows no significant leukocytes or erythrocytes. Educational objective: Explosive-onset nephrotic syndrome characterized by heavy proteinuria and profound hypoalbuminemia and that occurs shortly following an upper respiratory infection is typical for minimal change disease. Because the clinical phenotype does not accurately predict renal histopathology, most adults with non-diabetic nephrotic syndrome should undergo renal biopsy to confirm diagnosis and guide therapy.

stem: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation after a recent visit to the emergency department due to recurrent nephrolithiasis. The patient passed the stone spontaneously with supportive care alone. Analysis of the stone composition later revealed calcium oxalate crystals. The patient drinks 1 or 2 beers daily but does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. His diet consists of mostly processed foods and meats obtained at local stores, and he avoids fruits, vegetables, and dairy products. Vital signs are within normal parameters. BMI is 32~kg/m^{2} Physical examination is normal. Serum chemistry is normal. You provide affirmation of his desire to lose weight and recommend increasing his water intake. In addition to weight loss and increased fluid intake, which of the following is the best dietary recommendation to reduce the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis in this patient?
explanation: Nephrolithiasis occurs when supersaturated metabolites crystallize in the urine. Approximately 75% of kidney stones are calcium based (primarily calcium oxalate), and up to 50% of patients develop recurrent stones within 5 years. Dietary modifications can reduce the risk of stone formation, primarily by reducing urinary calcium and oxalate. In the past, patients were counseled to avoid calcium, but high dietary calcium intake actually decreases the risk of stone formation. Dietary calcium binds oxalate within the gastrointestinal tract, thereby decreasing systemic absorption of oxalate and subsequent excretion into the urine. However, supplemental (vs dietary) calcium may actually raise the risk of stone formation. If patients have recurrent stones despite dietary measures, medications (eg, thiazide diuretics, potassium citrate, allopurinol) may be needed to alter urine composition. (Choice A) Cranberry juice is often promoted to reduce the risk of urinary tract infections. However, its effect on the formation of calcium oxalate stones is unclear. Increasing dietary calcium is a better option to decrease the risk of stone formation. (Choice B) Despite prior recommendations, coffee, tea, and alcohol actually decrease the risk of calcium stone formation through their inhibition of antidiuretic hormone, leading to increased urine volume and decreased concentration of solutes (eg, calcium, oxalate). (Choice C) Reduction of high purine-containing foods (eg, seafood, organ meats) decreases uric acid production and is recommended for patients with uric acid stones, not calcium stones. (Choice E) Calcium is passively reabsorbed in the proximal tubule following sodium and water reabsorption. High sodium intake decreases proximal tubule sodium reabsorption and leads to increased urinary calcium levels, thereby raising the risk of calcium stone development. Educational objective: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common cause of nephrolithiasis. To reduce the risk of recurrent nephrolithiasis, patients should increase intake of fluids, dietary calcium, and fruits and vegetables, and decrease intake of sodium and animal protein.

stem: A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. His other medical problems include obesity and chronic kidney disease with a baseline creatinine of 1.5~mg/dL and urine protein excretion of 1100~mg/day. He has failed to lose weight despite diet adjustments and aerobic exercise. The patient takes insulin daily. His blood pressure is 140/89 mm Hg and his pulse is 83/min. Body mass index is 30~kg/m^{2}. He is started on lisinopril 5 mg daily. The patient returns for a follow-up appointment 2 weeks later and reports feeling well. His blood pressure is 133/85 mm Hg. Repeat testing shows creatinine of 1.8~mg/dL and potassium of 4.8~mEq/L. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Add irbesartan and repeat testing in 2-3 weeks
choice_b: Continue lisinopril and repeat testing in 2-3 weeks
choice_c: Discontinue lisinopril and repeat testing in 2-3 weeks
choice_d: Switch to amlodipine and repeat testing in 2-3 weeks
choice_e: Switch to valsartan and repeat testing in 2-3 weeks
explanation: This patient presents for management of diabetic nephropathy (ie, albuminuria of >300~mg/day or >300 mg/g creatinine on random urine sample). In addition to strict glycemic control and good blood pressure control (goal <140/90 mm Hg), inhibition of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system is a staple of therapy. Important side effects of angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) therapy include an expected initial decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) from reduced renal capillary pressure (due to greater relaxation of the efferent arteriole) and possible rise in serum potassium from reduced levels of aldosterone. These side effects should be monitored closely, especially at the outset of therapy or during dose titration. A rise in serum creatinine of up to 30%-35% from baseline is acceptable and should not cause discontinuation of therapy (Choice C). Moderate elevations in serum potassium ( (le5.1-5.5~mEq/L) above normal limits should lead to dose reductions, and more severe elevations that cannot be managed with diuretics warrant discontinuation of therapy. (Choice A) Studies examining the effects of combining ARB and ACE inhibitor therapy have demonstrated no significant benefits over monotherapy. However, they have shown an increase in adverse events, including higher rates of acute kidney injury requiring dialysis, hospitalization, severe hyperkalemia, and hypotension. (Choice D) Although good blood pressure control (goal <140/90 mm Hg) is associated with a number of improved outcomes in patients with diabetes and diabetic nephropathy, ACE inhibitor or ARB therapy is preferred over calcium channel blockers due to the additional renal protective effects. (Choice E) Current guidelines do not prefer ARB over ACE inhibitor therapy unless a patient is unable to tolerate an ACE inhibitor (eg, cough). Both classes of medications have similar reductions in GFR and elevations in serum potassium. Educational objective: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers are first-line medications for the management of diabetic nephropathy due to their renal protective effects. Both therapies are associated with a rise in serum creatinine of up to 30%-35% from baseline; this is acceptable and should not cause discontinuation of therapy.

stem: An 80-year-old man comes to the physician because of a skin rash on his legs. He also complains of mild fatigue and a poor energy level. He denies chest pain/pressure, orthopnea, or dyspnea with exertion. Two weeks ago, he underwent coronary arteriography for unstable angina and had a stent placed in his right coronary artery. His subsequent hospital course was uncomplicated. His other medical problems include hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and mild cognitive impairment. His current medications include low-dose aspirin, benazepril, atenolol, clopidogrel, hydrochlorothiazide, rosuvastatin, and glipizide. Clopidogrel was added after the stent placement. His blood pressure is 144/82 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. His lungs are clear on auscultation. There is a mottled, lace-like, purplish discoloration of both lower extremities from the mid-thigh downward. His pulses are 1+ bilaterally over the distal lower extremities. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 12.0~g/dL, Platelets 150,000~cells/mu L, Leukocyte count 8,500~cells/mu L. Differential: Neutrophils 60%, Eosinophils 13%, Lymphocytes 25%, Monocytes 2%. Serum chemistry: Sodium 136~mEq/L, Potassium 4.6 mEq/L, Chloride 98 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 22 mEq/L, Creatinine 2.9~mg/dL (1.4~mg/dL at discharge). Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.010, Protein +1, Blood negative, Glucose negative, Leukocyte esterase negative, White blood cells 10-20/hpf, Red blood cells 5-10/hpf. Urine (spot sample) Sodium 38~mEq/24 h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
choice_b: Acute kidney injury due to angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with renal atheroembolic disease (cholesterol crystal emboli), which usually occurs after manipulation of the aorta or other large arteries in patients with atherosclerotic disease. The existing atherosclerotic plaque usually breaks off and embolizes to multiple small arteries leading to tissue and/or organ ischemia. Diagnosis is suggested by subacute onset of acute kidney injury (AKI), particularly with extrarenal embolic disease such as livedo reticularis and cyanotic toes. A skin or kidney biopsy may be necessary in some patients with an unclear diagnosis. Treatment is largely supportive and directed against secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease with aspirin, statins, blood pressure control, and smoking cessation. (Choice A) Acute interstitial nephritis usually causes fever, rash, and eosinophilia. However, it is usually not associated with extra-renal disease such as livedo reticularis or cyanotic toes. (Choice B) Acute kidney injury due to angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors usually occurs soon after starting the drug and is not associated with an abnormal urinary sediment, as seen in this patient. (Choice D) Pre-renal azotemia usually presents with a spot urinary sodium concentration <20 mEq/L and normal urinary sediment. This patient's urinary sodium of 38 mEq/L and abnormal urine sediment makes this less likely. (Choice E) Although this patient is at risk, radiocontrast AKI usually resolves within two weeks and is not associated with eosinophilia and livedo reticularis. Educational objective: Atheroembolic disease usually presents with acute kidney injury after arteriography involving the aorta, and is associated with livedo reticularis and a cyanotic or gangrenous toe.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for an annual examination. He generally feels well, although when asked about urinary problems, the patient says that he urinates 2 or 3 times per night and occasionally has to strain to initiate urination. He takes no medications. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. His father died of prostate cancer at age 84. Temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 12/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Rectal examination reveals a prostate that is mildly enlarged, symmetric, and nontender. Rectal sphincter tone is normal. Urinalysis and serum creatinine level are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has lower urinary tract symptoms (eg, nocturia, hesitancy), most likely due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Other common BPH symptoms include urinary frequency and decreased force of stream. Examination may show prostate enlargement, but symptoms do not correlate well with prostate size. Initial evaluation should include urinalysis to rule out hematuria (eg, due to bladder cancer) and infection and serum creatinine to screen for obstructive renal injury. Many experts also advise prostate-specific antigen testing for patients with lower urinary tract symptoms. BPH symptoms usually progress gradually, but some patients may experience regression over time. Severity is often scored based on number of symptoms (eg, frequency, nocturia, weak urinary stream, hesitancy, intermittence, incomplete emptying, urgency). For those with mild symptoms, such as this patient, simple behavioral modifications may be adequate. Interventions include shifting fluid intake to earlier in the day, decreasing caffeine and alcohol intake, and double voiding to more thoroughly empty the bladder. (Choice B) When medication is indicated, alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists (eg, tamsulosin, terazosin) are the preferred first-line treatment. 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (eg, finasteride) are generally less effective and slower to act, and are most effective in men with a large prostate volume rather than in those with mild enlargement (as in this patient). (Choice C) Measuring postvoid residual volume is useful in patients with urge incontinence who are being considered for treatment with an anticholinergic agent or in those with BPH and symptoms of overflow incontinence (eg, involuntary leakage of urine). However, it is not indicated in patients with mild BPH symptoms. (Choice D) Abdominal ultrasound is indicated to evaluate obstructive uropathy or suspected hydronephrosis, which are less likely in this patient with mild symptoms and normal renal function. (Choice E) Urethrocystoscopy is not recommended for routine evaluation of BPH. It is typically used for patients with suspected calculi, urethral strictures, or bladder cancer, or for surgical planning in men with severe BPH. Educational objective: For patients with mild benign prostatic hyperplasia, simple behavioral modifications (eg, shifting fluid intake to earlier in the day, decreasing caffeine and alcohol intake, double voiding) may be adequate.

stem: An 80-year-old woman presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue, dizzy spells, and nausea. She has been followed for several years for osteoporosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, depression, and mild cognitive impairment. She was recently started on treatment for systolic hypertension. She lives independently with support provided by a visiting nurse three times weekly. She performs all of her own activities of daily living. Her current medications include alendronate, sertraline, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg supine and 139/75 mm Hg standing ( (160/75 mmHg during the previous visit), pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 14/min. She is 5' 5" (165 cm) and her BMI is 19~kg/m^{2} There is 2/6 ejection-type systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border without radiation to the carotids. Her lungs are clear. Muscle strength is preserved and deep tendon reflexes are symmetrical bilaterally. Her gait is mildly unsteady. Her mini-mental status exam score is 22/30 (1 year ago 27/30). Fingerstick glucose level is 220~mg/dL Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
explanation: This patient's symptoms are most likely due to hyponatremia; an occasional, but possibly fatal complication of thiazide diuretics. Thiazide-induced hyponatremia usually occurs within 1-2 weeks after starting the drug, more commonly in older woman with low body mass index. One study showed that 36% of patients had a plasma sodium <130~mEq/L and patients > age 70 had a 3.9 times higher risk of developing hyponatremia. Thiazide diuretics cause hyponatremia by increasing sodium and potassium excretion in the cortical distal tubule and increasing medullary water reabsorption. The concentrated urine leads to ADH-induced water retention, which further dilutes the serum and worsens the hyponatremia. Although they work in the loop of Henle to decrease sodium reabsorption and increase excretion, loop diuretics have a lower incidence of hyponatremia because they impair medullary water reabsorption and make the medulla less responsive to ADH-induced water retention. Patients with thiazide-induced hyponatremia usually appear clinically euvolemic but can present with dizzy spells, lethargy, malaise, vomiting, associated significant hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Treatment involves stopping the diuretic, replacing potassium, and giving normal saline for evidence of volume depletion. Hypertonic saline is reserved for patients with marked symptomatic hyponatremia. (Choice A) This patient's symptoms and signs suggest global central nervous system dysfunction rather than a focal cerebellar stoke. (Choice B) Hypercalcemia can result in fatigue, nausea, constipation, and impaired cognition. Although thiazide diuretics can mildly increase the serum calcium, they usually do not cause significant symptomatic hypercalcemia unless another cause for hypercalcemia is present. (Choice C) The osmotic force of hyperglycemia results in water movement out of cells to decrease cell volume, but this effect would be very small in this patient and less likely to cause her symptoms. (Choice E) Volume depletion is less likely in this patient without clinical findings such as orthostatic changes, tachycardia, or decreased skin turgor. Educational objective: Thiazide diuretics can lead to hyponatremia (more commonly than loop diuretics), especially in frail and elderly women with a low body mass index. Patients with nonspecific symptoms after starting thiazide diuretics should have laboratory evaluation of their electrolytes.

stem: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up of several issues. She is known to have longstanding hypertension, obesity, stress incontinence, and osteoarthritis. She measures her blood pressure at home twice a week, and the readings are usually 140/90-100 mm Hg. Her current medications include ibuprofen 1.2 g daily, atenolol 50 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, and enalapril 20 mg daily. Her blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg, pulse is 64/min, and BMI is 30{kg/m}^{2}. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations show no abnormalities. She has 1+ to 2+ pedal edema. The patient's laboratory studies reveal: Hematocrit 38%, Leukocyte count 7,500/mm^{3}. Chemistry panel: Serum sodium 140~mEq/L, Serum potassium 4.8~mEq/L, Chloride 102~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24~mEq/L, Serum creatinine 1.7~mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in hypertension management for this patient?
explanation: This patient has suboptimal blood pressure control on three anti-hypertensives and likely has NSAID-induced blood pressure elevation. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can cause kidney injury by either enhancing renal vasoconstriction, inducing interstitial nephritis, or causing glomerulonephritis (minimal change or membranous nephropathy). NSAIDs can cause sodium retention, attenuate the effect of diuretic agents (leading to increased blood pressure), and also blunt the blood pressure-lowering effects of several antihypertensive agents. In this patient, a trial of discontinuation of ibuprofen with observation of her blood pressure response is the most appropriate initial step. (Choice A) The addition of a fourth antihypertensive agent should be delayed until the response to stopping the NSAID is observed. (Choice B) Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can be associated with increased adrenergic neural traffic and hypertension. Evaluation for sleep apnea should be considered if her high blood pressure and edema do not resolve after discontinuing the NSAID. (Choice C) This patient's low pulse suggests adequate beta adrenergic blockade. A further increase in atenolol is unlikely to further lower her blood pressure and could result in worsened bradycardia. (Choice D) Increasing the hydrochlorothiazide dose may further increase the serum creatinine. A trial of discontinuing the ibuprofen would be the better first step. Educational objective: NSAIDs are commonly associated with elevations in blood pressure and can also affect the efficacy of anti-hypertensive agents. A trial of discontinuation of the NSAID should be considered in patients with suboptimal blood pressure control.

stem: A 47-year-old man comes to the office due to recurrent kidney stones. He passed his first stone 7 years ago and has subsequently passed 2 additional stones since then. Analysis of one of the stones revealed a stone content of 85% calcium oxalate and 15% calcium phosphate. His father and brother have both had kidney stones. His medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, mild intermittent asthma, and psoriasis. He takes esomeprazole several times per week and uses an albuterol inhaler as needed for shortness of breath. He is allergic to sulfa medications. His blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg and his pulse is 76/min. BMI is 27~kg/m^{2} The patient's blood work from 6 months ago is shown below: Hemoglobin 14~g/dL, Hematocrit 44%, Platelets 260,000/mu L, Leukocytes 8,100/mu L, Sodium 140~mEq/L, Potassium 4.0~mEq/L, Chloride 102 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24~mEq/L, Blood urea nitrogen 20~mg/dL, Creatinine 0.8~mg/dL, Calcium 10~mg/dL, Glucose 100~mg/dL, Phosphorus 3.0~mg/dL, Uric acid 4.0~mg/dL. The patient's current laboratory studies reveal: Urinalysis pH 5.6, Protein none, Blood negative, Red blood cells 1-2/hpf, White blood cells 1-2/hpf. 24-hour urine: Volume 1300~mL/24 h, Calcium 380 mg/24 h, Uric acid 600 {mg/24} h (normal: 240-755), Oxalate 30~mg/24 h (normal: <40), Citrate 240~mg/24 h (normal: 320-1240). Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
choice_e: Increase animal protein in the diet
explanation: This patient with urolithiasis has a low urinary volume and idiopathic hypercalciuria, the main factors predisposing him to stone development. Dietary changes may reduce the incidence of stone formation. Calcium undergoes passive reabsorption in the proximal tubule along with sodium and water. A low sodium diet (<2300 mg/24 h) leads to increased proximal tubule calcium and sodium reabsorption, decreased calcium excretion, and a reduced overall incidence of calcium stones. High sodium intake increases urinary calcium excretion and should be avoided. Citrate can form a complex with calcium, thereby decreasing calcium stone formation. Dietary sources of citrate, such as 4 oz of lemon juice, can also increase urinary citrate excretion. However, lower than normal 24-hour urinary citrate excretion (as seen in this patient) is a risk factor for calcium stone formation, and citrate supplementation would be indicated to decrease stone formation. (Choice B) Long-term use of proton pump inhibitors is associated with increased risk of bone fractures, Clostridioides difficile infection, and hypomagnesemia. Esomeprazole has not been associated with an increased risk of kidney stones, and discontinuation of the drug would worsen this patient's gastroesophageal reflux disease. (Choice C) Calcium intake has a paradoxical response in calcium stone formation. Higher dietary calcium intake may result in gastrointestinal binding of calcium oxalate, thereby reducing urinary excretion of calcium and oxalate. However, lower calcium intake could potentially increase urinary calcium oxalate excretion, increasing the risk for future stones. (Choice D) Vitamin D supplementation has been linked to an increased risk of kidney stones and should be avoided in this patient. (Choice E) High intake of animal protein can potentially contribute to calcium urolithiasis by increasing urinary calcium excretion, increasing urinary uric acid excretion (which can facilitate calcium stone formation), and lowering urinary pH. Educational objective: Hypercalciuria is a common risk factor for the formation of calcium-containing kidney stones. Several dietary factors can have a favorable impact in reducing the incidence of calcium stones.

stem: A 75-year-old man comes to the office for hypertension follow-up. The patient has been taking chlorthalidone since being diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago, and he was started on metoprolol 4 years ago after he had a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Over the last 2 years, his blood pressure measurements have ranged from 160/80 mm Hg to 180/100 mm Hg, and amlodipine was added to his medical regimen 6 months ago. The patient has had no chest pain, dyspnea, palpitation, headache, or subjective neurological deficits. His medical history includes hyperlipidemia and peripheral vascular disease, and other medications are aspirin and atorvastatin. The patient is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Today, blood pressure is 165/86 mm Hg and pulse is 68/min. Physical examination is notable for an abdominal bruit. Serum creatinine is 1.2~mg/dL, and duplex Doppler ultrasonography reveals >60\% stenosis of bilateral renal arteries. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This elderly patient who has uncontrolled hypertension despite multidrug therapy and is found to have high-grade bilateral renal artery stenosis should be treated with an ACE inhibitor. Bilateral renal ischemia (caused by limited blood supply to the poststenotic kidney) induces the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which leads to sodium retention and volume expansion. As the RAAS is involved, a combination of a diuretic with an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is the preferred initial treatment. ACE inhibitors have been shown to decrease mortality, rate of myocardial infarction, progression to end-stage renal disease, and stroke and are equally as effective as angioplasty in most patients. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are at increased risk of development of acute kidney injury; however, ACE inhibitors and ARBs are no longer thought to be contraindicated in this population as most patients only experience a small decline in glomerular filtration rate. More marked declines are usually reversible with dose reduction or elimination of the diuretic; patients should be monitored closely while on these medications. Other antihypertensive agents and statins, as well as antiplatelet therapy should be added when appropriate along with lifestyle changes. Patients who fail optimal medical therapy (eg, refractory hypertension, inability to tolerate medications, progressive renal insufficiency) or those with recurrent flash pulmonary edema or heart failure should undergo revascularization with stenting (Choice D). (Choice B) Although invasive renal angiography is considered the gold standard for diagnosis of renal artery stenosis, less invasive imaging (eg, ultrasound, MRI, CT scan) is preferred due to the risk of complications associated with angiography (eg, contrast load, cholesterol embolization). (Choice C) Plasma renin activity (PRA) measurements are useful to distinguish between primary and secondary hyperaldosteronism in patients with refractory hypertension. PRA is expected to be low in patients with primary hyperaldosteronism and elevated in patients with renovascular hypertension. However, up to 50% of patients with renovascular hypertension do not have an elevated PRA, and levels are suppressed by antihypertensives, high sodium diet, and bilateral renal artery disease, limiting the practical use of PRA measurement. (Choice E) Surgery is recommended for patients who have early primary branching of the main renal artery or multiple small renal arteries, have failed prior stenting, or require aortic reconstruction for other reasons (eg, aneurysm, aorto-iliac disease). Educational objective: Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis should first be treated with medical therapy (eg, a diuretic and either ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker) as it is as efficacious as angioplasty or surgery.

stem: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to acute flank pain and dysuria. He has no associated fever, joint pain, or suprapubic pain. The patient was discharged 5 days ago following hospitalization for central nervous system toxoplasmosis. He has long-standing AIDS (most recent CD4 count: 150/mm^{3} and had not been compliant with either antiretroviral treatment or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole prophylaxis therapy for several months prior to admission. While in the hospital, the patient was started on sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine, and antiretroviral treatment was reinstituted. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. Mucous membranes are dry. The abdomen is soft, and bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness is present. No rash is present. Laboratory studies are as follows: Complete blood count: Hemoglobin 10~g/dL, Platelets 140,000/mm^{3}, Leukocytes 11,000/mm^{3}. Differential: Neutrophils 75%, Eosinophils 1%, Lymphocytes 16%, Monocytes 8%. Serum creatinine 2.2~mg/dL (on discharge: 1.2~mg/dL). Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.016, PH 5.5, Protein +1, Blood moderate, White blood cells 20-30/hpf, Red blood cells 20-30/hpf. A urinary catheter is placed and produces 10 mL of urine during 6 hours of observation in the emergency department. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with hematuria, pyuria, and bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness. The recent initiation of sulfadiazine should raise suspicion for crystal-induced AKI, which occurs when poorly soluble drugs precipitate within the renal tubules. Factors favoring crystal formation include exposure to high doses of the drug, dehydration (increases intratubular concentration), and acidic urinary pH (occurs with uric acid, sulfonamides, and methotrexate). Patients are often asymptomatic, but can have flank pain symptoms typically occur within a week of drug initiation. Diagnosis is confirmed by observation of characteristic crystals on urinalysis when the patient is taking a known inciting drug. Hematuria and pyuria are also commonly noted. Nearly 30% of patients on sulfadiazine develop AKI, primarily due to the drug's insolubility at a urinary pH of ≤5.5. Sulfonamides can form needle-shaped, rosette, or clumped ("stacks of wheat") crystals that can be identified on urinalysis. Prevention and treatment of sulfadiazine-induced AKI include adequate hydration (3 L/day) and alkalinization of the urine to a pH of >7.15 to increase solubility. In patients with suspected sulfadiazine-induced AKI, renal ultrasound can be obtained to complete the evaluation but is unlikely to confirm the diagnosis. Ultrasonography can be normal, show sludge or small calyceal stones (due to sulfonamide precipitation), or reveal hydronephrosis (in rare cases where urolithiasis develops and causes obstructive uropathy). However, these findings are nonspecific and are unlikely to change initial management with fluids and urine alkalinization to solubilize the crystals. If urolithiasis is suspected in a nonpregnant patient, noncontrast CT scan is preferred to ultrasound as it is more sensitive and accurate (Choice B). (Choice A) Cystoscopy can detect bladder cancer or stones, which usually present with painless hematuria or irritative voiding symptoms. This patient's flank pain and costovertebral tenderness are more consistent with an upper urinary tract etiology. (Choice C) Pyelonephritis causes flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness, although it is typically unilateral. However, patients who develop AKI from pyelonephritis are typically quite ill; fever, chills, and hypotension would be expected. (Choice E) Acute interstitial nephritis commonly presents with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. Urinalysis classically shows urine eosinophils and white blood cell casts (not seen in this patient). In addition, pain is uncommon. Educational objective: Crystal-induced acute kidney injury occurs when poorly soluble drugs precipitate in the renal tubules. Sulfadiazine is insoluble at a pH of ≤5.5; prevention and treatment include hydration and alkalinization of the urine to a pH of >7.15 to increase solubility.

stem: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician with fever, chills, and painful urination for 3 days. He has also experienced decreased force in his urinary stream, urinary frequency, and nocturia. The patient was diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia 2 years ago. His other medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include saw palmetto, metformin, enalapril, and lovastatin. He is sexually active with his wife of 35 years. His temperature is 38.3^{circ} C (101^{circ}F), blood pressure is 127/84 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness bilaterally. His genitalia and testes are normal. His prostate is enlarged and very tender to palpation on digital rectal examination. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 46%, Leukocyte count 14,200/mm^{3}, Creatinine 1.2~mg/dL, Glucose 100~mg/dL. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.013, Protein Trace, Blood Trace, Glucose Negative, Leukocyte esterase Positive, White blood cells 20-30/hpf, Red blood cells 5-10/hpf. Urine and blood cultures are sent. Urine Gram stain shows no organisms. Which of the following would be the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is most consistent with acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP). Most cases are due to Gram-negative (eg, Escherichia coli, Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella, Enterobacter) organisms. Gram-positive (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococci, Enterococci) infections are less common and are usually due to remote infection elsewhere, prolonged catheterization, or recent prostatic surgery. Patients typically present with acute urinary complaints (eg, frequency, urgency, urge incontinence), pelvic/perineal pain, cloudy urine, and systemic symptoms (eg, fever, chills, malaise, myalgia). Digital examination shows an exquisitely tender prostate that is warm and edematous. Prostate massage is not recommended, however, due to pain and increased risk of bacteremia. In addition, prostate fluid is not necessary for diagnosis (Choice D). Evaluation includes urine Gram stain and culture. Empiric antibiotics that effectively penetrate the prostate (eg, oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole [TMP-SMX] or fluoroquinolone) are recommended. Intravenous antibiotics are recommended for septic-appearing patients. Oral antibiotics are usually continued for prolonged periods (eg, 4 weeks) and tailored to culture results. After the infection resolves, patients usually need urologic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. Chronic bacterial prostatitis (CBP) can be a complication of ABP due to inadequate duration of treatment. CBP tends to present with less severe urinary symptoms and without significant systemic findings. Most urologists obtain urine and prostate fluid specimens after prostate massage for diagnosis.
