Fluoroquinolones are the preferred first-line agent. Patients usually require a prolonged course of antibiotics ranging from 6 weeks to 6-12 months in some cases. (Choice A) Acute urinary retention is an infrequent complication of acute prostatitis, and bladder drainage must be done by suprapubic catheterization. Catheter insertion through the inflamed urethra into the bladder is contraindicated in acute prostatitis. (Choice B) Doxycycline is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis, which is more common in sexually active men and chronic bacterial prostatitis. It does not penetrate the prostate as well as fluoroquinolones or TMP-SMX and is not considered first-line therapy for ABP. (Choice E) Transrectal ultrasound can evaluate for suspected prostatic abscess or cancer. Prostate abscess can present similarly to prostatitis but usually has significant fluctuance on digital examination or persistent symptoms despite antibiotics. Educational objective: Management of acute prostatitis involves obtaining a urine culture followed by empiric treatment with fluoroquinolones or oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Prostate massage is not recommended. If bladder drainage is required, the suprapubic route should be used.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up evaluation of hematuria. He underwent evaluation for an insurance policy and was told that he had blood in his urine. He has never observed any blood in his urine; however, he has noticed a progressively weaker urinary stream over the past several years and often gets up to urinate at least twice each night. He has no history of flank or abdominal pain, and has never passed a kidney stone or had urinary tract infection. He has smoked more than one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He recently retired from many years of employment in the dye industry. He has been diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive lung disease, benign prostatic hypertrophy, degenerative joint disease, and hypertension. His current medications consist of an inhaler containing a beta adrenergic agonist, several over-the-counter NSAIDs, and lisinopril. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination findings are compatible with moderate chronic obstructive lung disease. A urinalysis performed in the office shows a positive dipstick and 3-5/hpf RBCs. Subsequently, 2 additional urinalyses are performed; RBCs are 1-2/hpf on the first and 5-10/hpf on the second urinalysis. Urine cytology is negative for malignant cells on 3 occasions. A CT scan of the kidneys is within normal limits. A urine culture is negative. The patient's laboratory studies reveal: Hematocrit 43%, Platelets 280,000/mu L, Leukocytes 9,100/mu L, Creatinine 1.2~mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
choice_a: Follow-up with urinalyses every 6 months; do further evaluation if hematuria increases
choice_e: Treat for benign prostatic hyperplasia, and see if the hematuria resolves
explanation: This patient has microscopic hematuria (defined as RBCs>3/hpf) along with several risk factors for bladder cancer (ie, age, gender, ethnicity, cigarette smoking history, and possible exposure to chemicals associated with bladder cancer). Chemicals associated with bladder cancer development include aromatic amines, arsenic, and other chemicals involved in the manufacture of dyes, rubber, leather, and textiles. As outlined in the figure, this patient had asymptomatic dipstick hematuria with microhematuria seen on subsequent urinalysis. Given his bladder cancer risk and presence of microhematuria on 1 of the 2 additional urine samples, imaging and urine cytology were performed. Because results of these studies were both negative, the next step would be cystoscopy to evaluate for bladder malignancy. (Choice A) Although the hematuria observed is low grade, this patient's risk profile for bladder cancer is high, and timely visualization of the bladder is appropriate to potentially diagnose an early stage cancer. (Choice B) Coagulation disorders rarely present as hematuria and are almost always associated with an abnormality within the genitourinary tract (eg, stone and tumor). This patient takes agents that may decrease platelet function (ie, NSAIDs), but coagulation studies would be low yield in this patient. (Choice D) With the CT scan showing no cause for the hematuria, MRI would be of very low diagnostic yield. (Choice E) Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) can cause gross hematuria, usually at either initiation or termination of micturition. Although the mechanism of hematuria in BPH remains unclear, prominent neovascularization can occur and lead to visualization of enlarged veins in the prostatic urethra on cystoscopy. In this high-risk patient, bladder cancer should initially be excluded. Educational objective: Advancing age, male sex, Caucasian ethnicity, cigarette smoking, exposure to selected chemicals, chronic bladder inflammation, and a family history of cancer are risk factors for bladder cancer. Hematuria in a patient with risk factors should promote a timely evaluation for cancer with imaging, urine cytology, and cystoscopy.

stem: A 75-year-old man comes for follow-up 6 months after radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer. He continues to have occasional episodes of involuntary loss of urine with activities such as straining or lifting heavy objects. The patient was an avid golfer but stopped after the surgery due to urinary leakage. He has no dysuria, nocturia, or hematuria. The patient did not undergo radiation therapy. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg and pulse is 68/min. The abdomen is soft and nontender without palpable masses. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick on bilateral feet. Ankle reflexes are absent and muscle strength is normal. Post-void residual volume is low. Prostate-specific antigen level is undetectable and urinalysis findings are within reference range. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: Urinary incontinence is a common complication after radical prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer and is usually due to urethral sphincter injury. Some studies show that up to 50% of patients can develop stress incontinence within 2 months of surgery, but the incidence dramatically decreases to ~10% by 2 years post surgery. As a result, nonsurgical treatment is initially preferred. Pelvic floor exercises with biofeedback can significantly accelerate recovery and decrease incidence of post-surgical urinary incontinence. Patients who fail conservative therapy (usually <1%) may require surgery with artificial sphincter placement or sling procedure. (Choice A) MRI of the lumbosacral spine can evaluate for neurogenic bladder due to spinal cord lesions. Patients usually develop lower extremity weakness with bowel/bladder incontinence. This patient's normal muscle strength makes this less likely. The absent ankle reflexes can be due to normal aging (most common after age 70) and are not clinically significant. (Choice C) Retrograde urethrogram can detect urethral strictures due to bladder neck contracture or distal urethral narrowing post prostatectomy. Patients usually develop urinary retention with decreased urinary stream or overflow incontinence. The post-void residual is usually increased. (Choice D) Sildenafil can improve erectile dysfunction after radical prostatectomy. However, it is not useful for urinary incontinence. (Choice E) Tolterodine is an antimuscarinic drug for urge incontinence due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. However, this patient's prostatectomy makes this unlikely. No medications have yet been approved in the United States for the treatment of stress incontinence. Educational objective: Urinary incontinence is a common complication after radical prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer and is usually due to a damaged urinary sphincter. Pelvic floor exercises with biofeedback can significantly accelerate recovery and decrease the incidence of postprostatectomy stress incontinence.

stem: A 54-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy and hypertension comes to the office due to easy fatigability and tiredness. The patient experienced similar symptoms 6 months ago, but they improved after starting erythropoietin therapy for anemia. Over the past several weeks, the symptoms have recurred but she has had no chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, syncope, melena, or hematochezia. The patient receives 3-4 hours of maintenance hemodialysis 3 times a week. She has no drug allergies. Blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min with no orthostatic changes. She weighs 68 kg (150 lbs), which is her 'dry weight'. There are no heart murmurs. Abdominal examination shows no organomegaly and stool occult blood testing is negative. Laboratory studies are as follows: Hemoglobin 8.4~g/dL, Mean corpuscular volume 86~mu m^{3}, Serum potassium 4.8~mEq/L, Ferritin 182~ng/mL, Transferrin saturation 20%, Folate Normal, Vitamin $B{12}$ Normal. Hemoglobin was 8.2~g/dL and 10.1~g/dL 6 months and 4 months ago, respectively. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's anemia?
explanation: This patient initially had an appropriate response to erythropoietin-stimulating agent (ESA) therapy but now has worsening anemia. Iron deficiency is the most common cause of erythropoietin resistance. Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) are at risk for iron deficiency due to: Absolute iron deficiency: Blood loss (eg, gastrointestinal, blood draws) or vigorous hematopoiesis during ESA therapy. Functional iron deficiency: Impaired mobilization of iron due to elevated hepcidin levels (ie, anemia of chronic disease) or because iron cannot be mobilized rapidly enough to keep up with hematopoiesis after ESA administration. Normocytic anemia can be seen in the early stages of absolute iron deficiency (ie, before microcytosis develops) as well as in functional iron deficiency (ie, anemia of chronic disease), explaining this patient's normal mean corpuscular volume. The diagnosis of absolute iron deficiency in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is complex and is commonly based on parameters such as low transferrin saturation (eg, le20%) and ferritin (eg, le200~ng/mL in hemodialysis patients) levels. All patients with ESRD on ESA therapy should be treated with iron, regardless of the results of iron studies, unless ferritin >500~ng/mL. It is likely that this patient had limited iron stores that were rapidly depleted following initiation of ESA therapy. For completion, she should also be evaluated for gastrointestinal blood loss. (Choices B and D) Pure red blood cell aplasia is a hypoproliferative disorder that can be caused by anti-erythropoietin antibodies. Other hypoproliferative disorders (eg, myelodysplastic syndrome) can be diagnosed with bone marrow biopsy. However, hypoproliferative disorders are associated with increased serum iron levels due to reduced iron utilization. In addition, the brand of epoetin alfa most commonly associated with anti-erythropoietin antibodies has been removed from the market. Although bone marrow biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis of absolute iron deficiency, parameters such as transferrin saturation and ferritin are commonly used to identify it in patients with CKD. (Choice C) Inadequate hemodialysis can cause ESA hyporesponsiveness, but this patient has maintained her dry weight and does not have symptoms of volume overload. (Choice E) Red blood cell transfusions come with significant risks (eg, volume overload, transfusion reaction) and are reserved for severe anemia (hemoglobin <7 g/dL) in patients unresponsive to ESAs after iron supplementation. Educational objective: Iron deficiency is the most common cause of erythropoietin resistance in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). All patients with ESRD receiving erythropoietin-stimulating agents should be treated with intravenous iron, regardless of results of iron studies unless ferritin >500~ng/mL.

stem: A 63-year-old woman with a long history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for a progressive decline in renal function. She has no new complaints except for occasional tiredness and lower back pain. Her other medical problems include hypertension, obesity, mild diabetic retinopathy, and peripheral neuropathy. One year ago, she was evaluated for atypical chest pain and had a negative exercise stress test. She is a lifetime non-smoker. Her current medications include insulin, amlodipine, and low-dose aspirin. She was treated with lisinopril, which has been stopped recently due to renal dysfunction and hyperkalemia. Her current eGFR is 15~ml/min, potassium is 5.1~mEq/L, and hemoglobin is 10.2~g/dL. Which of the following would provide the highest survival benefit in this patient?
choice_d: Hemodialysis at onset of uremia symptoms
explanation: Diabetes mellitus is the most common cause of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requiring dialysis, and the 5-year survival for these patients on hemodialysis is around 30-40% (> 50% deaths from cardiovascular disease). Studies show diabetics with ESRD receiving kidney transplant had a 5-year survival of 67-77% and better quality of life. As a result, renal transplant should be offered to all eligible diabetics with ESRD. While a living related donor transplant is the best option, cadaveric transplant also offers increased survival in diabetic patients. Improved survival in diabetics following a cadaveric kidney transplant is maximal in younger age groups but is seen in all age groups, including patients > age 70. (Choices B & D) The optimal time to start dialysis is debated. Studies have shown no difference in outcomes between preemptive dialysis (GFR of 10-15~ml/min/1.73m^{2} without symptoms of uremia) and dialysis at either the onset of uremic symptoms or when the glomerular filtration rate is <10~ml/min/1.73m^{2}. (Choice C) Erythropoietin offers symptomatic relief from anemia of renal failure and indirectly improves cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, but renal transplant offers a higher survival benefit. (Choice E) Peritoneal dialysis is an option for maintenance dialysis in diabetics with stable cardiovascular dynamics, no severe vascular disease, or without advanced neuropathy. Survival with chronic peritoneal dialysis is generally comparable to chronic hemodialysis, but is not better than renal transplant. Educational objective: Diabetics with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) treated with either a living related or cadaveric donor kidney transplant (compared to dialysis) have better survival, quality of life, and rehabilitation. Infections are the most common cause of death in the early post-transplant period.

stem: A 60-year-old man with a past medical history of hypertension comes to the physician complaining of urinary symptoms. Over the last 6 months, he has had a decreased urinary stream and an occasional uncomfortable sensation while urinating. He awakens once a night to urinate but sometimes feels that he needs to go again. The symptoms do not bother him much at this point, but he is afraid that they may worsen. He has no family history of prostate problems. He has no fever, malaise, back pain, cloudy urine, or blood in the urine. Digital rectal examination shows a moderately enlarged and rubbery prostate. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 14.2~g/dL, Creatinine 0.9~mg/dL, Prostate-specific antigen 10.2~ng/mL (N:<4~ng/mL). Urinalysis: WBC 0-2/hpf, RBC 0-2/hpf, Protein Trace. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation of irritative and obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms, normal urinalysis, large prostate without a focal lesion, and prostate-specific antigen (PSA)>10~ng/mL is consistent with a prostatic disorder. PSA values have a log-linear relationship with prostate volume. However, elevated PSA has a lower specificity for prostatic cancer in men with obstructive symptoms than asymptomatic men. Prostate cancer screening is an individualized decision, and clinicians should first discuss the risks and benefits. If the patient prefers screening, most clinicians perform a digital rectal examination (DRE) and test serum PSA. Patients with normal DRE and PSA<3~ng/mL may be followed routinely. Men with PSA >7~ng/mL or abnormal DRE should be referred to a urologist for possible biopsy. Patients with PSA of 3-7~ng/mL should be retested in a few weeks and referred to a urologist if PSA remains >3~ng/mL (Choice C). Although the most common cause of elevated PSA is benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), the positive predictive value of a PSA>10 for prostate cancer is 15%-40%. Thus, this patient should be referred to a urologist. (Choices A and B) 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors and alpha-1-adrenergic blockers may relieve moderate to severe BPH symptoms. Treatment usually requires several weeks for optimal effect. However, this patient's mild BPH symptoms and elevated PSA require further investigation. (Choice E) A renal ultrasound would not be helpful with a normal serum creatinine. However, transrectal prostatic ultrasound can help guide prostate biopsy in selected cases. Educational objective: Patients with a normal digital rectal examination (DRE) and prostate-specific antigen (PSA)<3~ng/mL may be followed routinely. Men with PSA>7~ng/ml or abnormal DRE should be referred to a urologist for possible biopsy.

stem: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up on cadaveric renal transplantation done 10 months ago for polycystic kidney disease. His postoperative course was complicated by 2 episodes of acute rejection and an episode of lower gastrointestinal bleeding. These events prompted revision of his immunosuppressive regimen, which now includes prednisone, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, and acyclovir. The patient has no new symptoms. His only other medical problem is diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. His blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. His BMI is 29{kg/m}^{2} There are no skin rashes. The spleen tip is not palpable. There is no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 12.0~g/dL, Potassium 3.8~mEq/L, Creatinine 2.7~mg/dL, HemoglobinA1c 7.4%. Urinalysis: Protein +1, Glucose Present, White blood cells 20-30/hpf, Red blood cells 20-30/hpf. Urine sediment analysis shows cellular casts. Cytology demonstrates atypical cells with intranuclear inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient most likely has human polyoma virus infection. There is a high prevalence of seropositivity of polyoma virus (eg, BK and JC) in the general population, but polyoma viruses cause disease only in immunosuppressed individuals. In renal transplant recipients, the BK form of polyoma virus produces tubulointerstitial nephritis and, less commonly, ureteric stenosis. The mean time of onset of BK infection is 10-15 months after transplantation. BK viral infection is most common in older men with type 2 diabetes mellitus and rejection episodes with significant immunosuppression. There are no characteristic clinical manifestations other than loss of renal function. The presence of cells with a single large basophilic intranuclear inclusion found on urine cytology suggests but does not prove BK infection. Serology is not as useful as many in the general population have antibodies against the virus. Renal biopsy findings can be similar to those in other viral infections (eg, cytomegalovirus). As a result, diagnosis requires renal biopsy showing characteristic cytopathology plus positive antibodies directed specifically against BK on immunohistochemistry tests. Biopsy sometimes misses the diagnosis, and at least 2 biopsy cores may be required in suspected patients. The primary treatment is reduction of immunosuppression. (Choice A) Allograft rejection can cause progressive renal dysfunction and may be difficult to differentiate clinically from BK infection. However, allograft rejection does not typically cause intranuclear inclusions on urine cytology. (Choice B) Diabetic nephropathy can recur after renal transplantation but usually presents several years after transplantation with significant proteinuria, which is not seen in this patient. (Choice C) Epstein-Barr virus may cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder, which is due to both lymphoid and/or plasma cell proliferation in the transplanted organ/tissue. Patients may present with an infectious mononucleosis-like illness or nonspecific constitutional symptoms (eg, weight loss and fatigue) but usually do not have worsening renal function. (Choice E) The calcineurin inhibitors, including cyclosporine and tacrolimus, are potentially nephrotoxic. An acute nephrotoxicity is due to renal vasoconstriction and is often reversed by dosage reduction. A chronic form is due to vasculopathic changes in the kidney and is usually not reversible. Calcineurin inhibitors are not associated with intranuclear inclusions, and this patient's course is more characteristic of BK viral infection. Educational objective: BK polyoma virus presents in renal transplant recipients most commonly after rejection and significant immunosuppression. Patients typically develop tubulointerstitial nephritis with rising creatinine and the presence of intranuclear inclusions in urine cells. Definitive diagnosis requires renal biopsy plus positive immunohistochemistry tests using antibodies directed specifically against the BK virus.

stem: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up after the passage of a kidney stone. He was evaluated in the emergency department 10 days ago for right-sided colicky flank pain. An abdominal CT scan at that time revealed a 7-mm stone at the right ureteropelvic junction and two stones near the tips of calyces in the left kidney. The patient spontaneously passed the stone, but was not able to retrieve it for analysis. He has not previously had symptoms of kidney stones. His review of systems is normal. He is in good health, takes no medication or vitamins, is not chronically dehydrated, and has no family history of kidney stones. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows occasional hexagonal crystals with benzene ring morphology. Which of the following analyses performed on a 24-hour urine collection is most likely to lead to the diagnosis?
explanation: In a young patient with several kidney stones and typical cystine (hexagonal green/yellow) crystals on urinalysis, cystinuria is the most likely diagnosis. Cystinuria is a rare autosomal recessive disease that can lead to multiple kidney stones and complications such as obstructive uropathy, urinary tract infections, and loss of kidney function. Increased fluid intake to produce a higher urine volume, alkalinization of the urine (with potassium citrate or bicarbonate), and chelating agents (in some cases) can prevent further cystine stone formation. Patients with large stones or with urinary obstruction require referral to urology for stone removal. (Choice A) In the United States, >80% of the stones passed contain calcium. Hypercalciuria is a common predisposing factor in calcium-containing stone formers. Examination shows envelope-shaped crystals. (Choice B) Citrate appears to slow the growth of calcium crystals, and low urinary excretion of citrate is a factor that can contribute to stone formation. Urinary citrate measurement is not diagnostically helpful in this patient with cystinuria. (Choice D) Increased urinary excretion of oxalate is seen in inherited oxalate metabolism disorders and in malabsorption. In this patient with cystine crystals on urinalysis, measurement of the urinary excretion of oxalate is not diagnostically helpful. (Choice E) Increased urinary excretion of uric acid, along with low pH, contributes to uric acid stone formation. In some cases, increased urinary excretion of uric acid may also contribute to calcium stone formation by decreasing the solubility of calcium oxalate. Examination shows rhomboid crystals. Educational objective: Suspect cystinuria in patients with large branched calculi or a first stone occurring at an early age (childhood or adolescence). Hexagonal (benzene ring) crystals are seen in 25% of the patients on initial urinalysis. Increased fluid intake, alkalinization of the urine (with potassium citrate or bicarbonate), and chelating agents (in some cases) can prevent further cystine stone formation.

stem: A 58-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office for a follow-up visit. Medical history also includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and osteoarthritis. He has diabetic nephropathy with a baseline creatinine of 2.0-2.5~mg/dL. The patient's mobility is impaired due to right knee osteoarthritis and diabetic neuropathy. Medications include acetaminophen, insulin, metoprolol, valsartan, chlorthalidone, aspirin, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 159/102 mm Hg and pulse is 68/min. BMI is 36~kg/m^{2}. Physical examination shows 2+ bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum creatinine 2.4~mg/dL, Serum potassium 5.4~mg/dL, Hemoglobin A1c 7.5%, 24-hour urine protein excretion 1.2~g/L. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has uncontrolled hypertension despite multiple antihypertensive medications. In addition, he is at increased risk for complications due to underlying diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). Patients with CKD should have a target blood pressure of <140/90 mm Hg, and many experts recommend even more aggressive control. ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) (eg, valsartan) are first-line antihypertensive agents in patients with proteinuric CKD (ie, proteinuria >500~mg/day). For patients who have persistent hypertension despite first-line therapy, a diuretic or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (eg, diltiazem, verapamil) may be added. Diuretics are especially useful for patients with edema (such as this patient) as euvolemia can increase the effectiveness of other antihypertensives. However, thiazide diuretics (eg, chlorthalidone) are less effective in patients with creatinine clearance <30 mL/min/1.73 m^{2}, these patients should be transitioned to loop diuretics (eg, furosemide). If loop diuretics alone are ineffective at improving edema, a thiazide may be added again to improve diuresis. The addition of furosemide would likely reduce this patient's mild hyperkalemia as well. (Choices A and D) This patient is appropriately on an ARB (valsartan). There is little benefit in substituting an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril) for an ARB beyond cost considerations and a slightly reduced rate of symptomatic hypotension. Adding an ACE inhibitor to an ARB is not recommended as combined therapy is associated with an increased risk of hypotension and hyperkalemia. (Choices B and E) Calcium channel blockers (eg, amlodipine) and aldosterone antagonists (eg, spironolactone) are excellent options for third-or fourth-line therapy in proteinuric CKD. However, non-dihydropyridine blockers are preferred over dihydropyridines due to their effect on proteinuria. Also, aldosterone antagonists may worsen this patient's hyperkalemia. Educational objective: In patients with hypertension and proteinuric chronic kidney disease, diuretics can correct edema and increase the effectiveness of other antihypertensive medications. Loop diuretics are more effective than thiazide diuretics in patients with creatinine clearance <30 mL/min/1.73 m².

stem: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated for intermittent claudication prior to angiography. At a recent evaluation, her ankle-brachial index was 0.65 on the right and 0.75 on the left. The patient has a history of long-term cigarette smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe degenerative arthritis of the knees. Current medications include simvastatin, ibuprofen, glipizide, and amlodipine. Blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the base. The lungs are clear and there is no jugular venous distension. Tibial pulses are 1+ and the patient has trace pedal edema of the ankles bilaterally. Serum creatinine is 2~mg/dL and urinalysis shows 2+ proteinuria. In addition to using the smallest dose of a third-generation contrast agent and prehydrating with normal saline, which of the following is the most appropriate precaution for this patient's angiography?
choice_b: Furosemide during and following the procedure
choice_d: Mannitol prior to and during the procedure
explanation: This patient with chronic kidney disease is at risk for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) from her impending angiography. The etiology of CIN likely includes both direct cytotoxicity and renal vasoconstriction. Acute kidney injury (eg, elevated creatinine, electrolyte abnormalities) develops 24-48 hours after contrast administration, and patients often have a low fractional excretion of sodium (<1%), even in the absence of clinical volume depletion. Although the risk of CIN is negligible in patients with normal renal function, patients with chronic kidney disease (particularly those with diabetic nephropathy) are at increased risk. Additional risk factors include the use of large contrast volumes and older, first-generation contrast agents. Preventive measures include avoidance of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (which can worsen vasoconstriction), periprocedural infusion of normal saline, and use of the smallest possible volume of contrast media. (Choices B, C, D, and E) Other suggested measures for preventing CIN include agents to force diuresis (eg, mannitol, furosemide), prevent renal vasoconstriction (eg, dopamine, fenoldopam), rapidly remove contrast material (eg, hemodialysis), or inhibit oxidative stress (eg, acetylcysteine). However, none has been shown to have a clear benefit. Educational objective: Patients with chronic kidney disease are at risk for contrast-induced nephropathy. Preventive measures include avoidance of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, periprocedural infusion of normal saline, and use of the smallest possible volume of contrast media.

stem: A 63-year-old man, who was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago, comes to the office for a follow-up appointment. Over the last 2 weeks, he has noticed mild swelling in his legs, as well as fatigue. He has had no shortness of breath, orthopnea, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Over the past year, the patient was found to have albuminuria on 2 separate visits. Three months ago, blood pressure was 122/78 mm Hg, serum creatinine was 1.2~mg/dL urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio was 250~mg/g and hemoglobin A1c was 7.2%. Lisinopril was initiated a year ago and the dose was increased 3 months ago. The patient has had no recent viral illnesses or taken any new medications. Current medications include low-dose aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and glargine insulin. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg and pulse is 85/min. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is nontender and no costovertebral angle tenderness. The patient has 2+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum chemistry: Sodium 132~mEq/L, Potassium 4.8~mEq/L, Chloride 102~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 22~mEq/L, Blood urea nitrogen 26~mg/dL, Creatinine 1.8~mg/dL, Glucose 138~mg/dL, Albumin 3.1~g/dL, Calcium 8.2~mg/dL. Urinalysis: Glucose negative, Bacteria none, White blood cells 20-30/hpf, Red blood cells 20-30/hpf, Casts red blood cell casts, Protein 3+. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.5%. A renal ultrasonogram shows symmetric, normal-sized kidneys with no evidence of hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Adjust insulin dose for strict glycemic control and follow-up in several weeks
choice_c: Discontinue lisinopril and repeat laboratory testing in several weeks
choice_e: Obtain duplex Doppler ultrasonography of the renal arteries
explanation: Diabetic nephropathy and nondiabetic glomerular diseases (eg, glomerulonephritis) can have similar presentations; however, these conditions must be differentiated from each other as their clinical course and treatment differs. Diabetic nephropathy commonly presents with albuminuria and a bland urinalysis, although hematuria and red blood cell casts can sometimes be seen. Diabetic nephropathy is slowly progressive; it typically takes years from the onset of albuminuria to the development of overt renal failure. Glomerulonephritis commonly presents with active urinary sediment (eg, hematuria, pyuria, red blood cell casts) and hypertension. It is typically rapidly progressive and may require specific anti-inflammatory therapy (eg, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants) to prevent development of end-stage renal disease. This patient with diabetes mellitus and a history of albuminuria now has a rapid decline in GFR, development of progressive hypertension despite an increased ACE inhibitor dose, a significant increase in proteinuria (3+ corresponds to a urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio >1,000~mg/g) with accompanying edema, and active urinary sediment; this constellation of findings makes glomerulonephritis likely. Renal biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis. Nondiabetic glomerular diseases should also be considered in patients with marked renal dysfunction (>30% decrease in glomerular filtration rate [GFR]) after ACE inhibitor initiation or with symptoms of systemic disease. (Choice A) Excellent glucose control can cause a regression in diabetic nephropathy; however, this patient already has relatively good glycemic control (hemoglobin A1c of 7.5%), and his rapidly progressive course makes diabetic nephropathy less likely. (Choice B) Changing from an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril) to an angiotensin receptor blocker (eg, valsartan) is recommended for patients who experience ACE-associated cough; it would not improve serum creatinine. (Choices C and E) Increased serum creatinine is common in patients on ACE inhibitor therapy, but the increase is usually modest (<30% decline in GFR). A more marked decline may occur with bilateral renal artery stenosis. However, renal artery stenosis should not cause active urinary sediment, and this patient tolerated an ACE inhibitor for a year without kidney injury. It is unlikely that the increased dose would cause such a rapid reduction in GFR. Educational objective: Diabetic nephropathy typically presents with bland urinalysis and albuminuria; however, hematuria and red blood cell casts may occur. Progression is slow (years); therefore, nondiabetic glomerular diseases should be considered in patients with rapidly progressive disease, unexpected reductions in glomerular filtration rates (>30%) after ACE inhibitor initiation, active urinary sediment, or symptoms of other systemic diseases.

stem: A 60-year-old woman is being evaluated for headache and hypertension. For the past week, she has felt tired and has had a progressive, generalized headache. She denies fever, chills, photophobia, or neck stiffness. Her general health has been good with the exception of 6 months of persistent pains and swelling in both hands. During this time, her fingers felt puffy and she recently noted some tiny pits appearing on her finger tips. She is also troubled by heartburn and mild dyspnea with exertion. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes calcium, vitamin D, and a multivitamin. Over the past few days, she has also been taking acetaminophen and ibuprofen. Her blood pressure is 210/111 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. She looks her stated age and appears uncomfortable. Her ocular fundi reveal no papilledema. Her neck is supple. Cardiac and abdominal exams are within normal limits. She has bibasilar fine end-inspiratory crackles on pulmonary exam. There are a few small digital fingertip pits. Her laboratory studies are shown below: Complete blood count: Hematocrit 33%, Platelets 130,000~cells/mu L, Leukocyte count 9,200~cells/mu L. Serum chemistry panel: Sodium 140~mEq/L, Potassium 3.8~mEq/L, Chloride 98~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24~mEq/L, Creatinine 2.8~mg/dL, Blood glucose 100~mg/dL, INR 1.0, Partial thromboplastin time 30 seconds. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.019, Protein trace, Blood negative, Casts none. Her chest-x ray shows bibasilar reticular fibrosis. Her peripheral blood smear reveals schistocytes. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation (joint pains, finger puffiness, digital tip pits, gastroesophageal reflux, and basilar interstitial lung disease) is most consistent with scleroderma. Severe and life-threatening renal disease develops in 10-20% of patients with the cutaneous form of scleroderma, known as scleroderma renal crisis. Intense renal vasoconstriction stimulates the release of renin and generation of angiotensin II, which worsens the hypertension and leads to progressive renal dysfunction. Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors can decrease progression of scleroderma renal failure, even in the presence of significant renal dysfunction (as in this patient). Captopril is preferred due to its rapid onset of action and extensive reported use in scleroderma renal crisis. The treatment should be continued even if renal function initially worsens, and some patients may need dialysis following long-term control of blood pressure with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors. (Choices B and C) Clonidine and Metoprolol are not first-line agents for hypertensive emergencies and do not prevent the effects of angiotensin II on renal vasoconstriction. (Choice D) Nifedipine can lower blood pressure quickly and may treat Raynaud's phenomena (seen in some scleroderma patients), but it is not effective for scleroderma renal crisis. (Choice E) Malignant hypertension and scleroderma renal crisis are often associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and platelet destruction. In patients with TTP-HUS, marked thrombocytopenia and anemia are seen. This patient has severe hypertension, pulmonary fibrosis, and cutaneous findings which are not seen with TTP-HUS. As a result, there is no indication for plasmapheresis in this patient. Educational objective: A subset of patients with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis develop scleroderma renal crisis, characterized by acute kidney injury (no active urinary sediment), accelerated hypertension, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Treatment involves prompt initiation of an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (even in patients with advanced renal dysfunction).

stem: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of severe left flank pain and gross hematuria. The pain started about 6 hours earlier and has steadily increased. It is not colicky in nature. There is no history of trauma, bleeding, or bruising. The patient has no weight loss, fever, chills, or dysuria. She considers herself in good health and works full-time as an editorial assistant. There is no family history of hematuria, kidney stones, or kidney disease. Her past medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. On examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Some scattered small pits are noted in her teeth. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable. An ill-defined mass is felt in the left flank area on abdominal examination. Laboratory results show a urinalysis with red bloods cells too numerous to count, normal complete blood count, and normal comprehensive metabolic panel. An urgent ultrasound reveals a 10-cm echogenic mass in the left kidney. Smaller echogenic masses and 3 renal cysts are seen in the right kidney. Abdominal CT scan reveals a 10x13-cm mass in the left kidney with attenuation similar to perirenal fat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with likely tuberous sclerosis complex, an autosomal dominant disorder due to mutations in 1 of 2 tumor suppressor genes. However, nearly 60% of cases involve no family history and are caused by new germline mutations. Tuberous sclerosis complex usually presents with hamartomatous tumors in many organs, including the brain, heart, lungs, kidney, and skin. Patients may present early in life with mental dysfunction, seizures, skin findings (eg, cutaneous angiomas), and dental pitting. However, recent studies have documented more adult-onset cases due to inability to recognize characteristic skin and dental findings in childhood or to later development of skin and dental pits. Adult-onset tuberous sclerosis complex may present with renal angiomyolipomas (as in this patient) or cystic lung disease, termed lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), in later life. The renal lesions may cause pain, hemorrhage, hematuria, and loss of kidney function. The pulmonary lesions can cause dyspnea, pneumothorax, hemoptysis, and loss of lung function. Many adults have normal cognitive function. Management usually involves seizure control and surveillance for CNS, pulmonary, and renal manifestations as many of the hamartomatous tumor complications are treatable. (Choice A) This patient's echogenic renal mass with attenuation similar to perirenal fat strongly suggests angiomyolipoma in the kidneys. Bilateral renal cell cancer is uncommon, and renal angiomyolipomas rarely (<2% of cases) become malignant. (Choice B) Neurofibromatosis typically does not involve the kidneys. (Choice C) Polycystic kidney disease is not usually associated with angiomyolipomas of the kidney. However, tuberous sclerosis complex is sometimes associated with renal cysts. (Choice E) von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant disorder presenting with hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, retinal angiomas, pheochromocytoma, pancreatic lesions, renal cysts, and renal cell carcinoma. This patient's illness is not characteristic of von Hippel-Lindau disease. Educational objective: Tuberous sclerosis complex is being recognized more frequently in adults. Patients who present with >1 renal angiomyolipoma or pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis in women should undergo a thorough dermatologic examination and brain imaging to screen for tuberous sclerosis. Management usually involves seizure control and surveillance for CNS, pulmonary, and renal manifestations.

stem: A 36-year-old woman has increasing nausea and headaches 12 hours after a right-sided percutaneous nephrolithotomy for staghorn calculi. The procedure involved ultrasonic lithotripsy followed by fragment removal using a flexible nephroscope. The patient spent a prolonged period in recovery and has been drowsy since returning to the ward. She is receiving intermittent morphine for pain control. She also received intravenous ceftriaxone after an episode of postoperative low-grade fever. Other medical conditions include frequent urinary tract infections, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and angioedema. A month ago, the patient was treated for contact dermatitis from poison ivy with a 10-day course of prednisone. Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 64/min, respirations are 14/min and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient is drowsy but arousable with a short attention span. Pupils are small but reactive to light and accommodation. Mucous membranes are moist. The neck is supple, and cardiovascular and lung examinations are unremarkable. Abdominal examination reveals diminished bowel sounds. The patient is able to move all extremities on command, and deep tendon reflexes are symmetric. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 36%, Leukocytes 10,000/mm^{3}, Sodium 119~mEq/L, Potassium 3.6~mEq/L, Chloride 90~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 22~mEq/L, Creatinine 0.8~mg/dL, Glucose 120~mg/dL. The patient's preoperative laboratory studies were normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_b: 500 mL bolus of normal saline followed by infusion
choice_e: Random cortisol level and intravenous dexamethasone
explanation: This patient, who is experiencing nausea, headaches, and drowsiness following lithotripsy, has acute symptomatic hyponatremia, likely related to her recent surgery. Postoperative hyponatremia can develop within hours of surgery due to release of vasopressin related to surgical stress, the use of nonelectrolyte solutions (eg, glycine, sorbitol) for irrigation, or the infusion of hypotonic solutions during surgery. Patients with hyponatremia may be asymptomatic, or they may have mild (eg, headache, nausea, vomiting, confusion) or severe (eg, seizure, obtundation, coma) symptoms. Untreated patients may develop cerebral edema and brain herniation. Management depends on hyponatremia chronicity and associated symptoms: Patients with acute (<24-48 hours) hyponatremia who are symptomatic, such as this patient, should be treated emergently with hypertonic saline while being carefully monitored. The goal is to relieve symptoms and increase the sodium level relatively rapidly (eg, 4-6 mEq/L within the first few hours); the correction rate should not exceed 8 mEq/L in 24 hours. Regardless of hyponatremia chronicity, patients with severe symptoms and those with intracranial pathology (eg, intracranial tumor, recent traumatic brain injury) should also receive hypertonic saline. In patients who do not require hypertonic saline, including most patients with chronic hyponatremia, serum sodium levels should be increased slowly; treatment depends on the underlying disease (eg. fluid restriction in hypervolemic patients, normal saline in hypovolemic patients). (Choice B) This patient needs relatively rapid correction of hyponatremia with hypertonic saline to prevent further deterioration in mental status; this cannot be achieved with an isotonic solution such as normal saline. In addition, her physical examination findings (eg, moist mucous membranes, lack of hypotension) do not suggest volume depletion. (Choice C) This patient already received ceftriaxone and does not have signs of sepsis (eg, tachycardia, hypotension) to warrant a change in antibiotics or blood cultures. Her mental status changes are more likely due to hyponatremia. (Choice D) The mechanism of the neurological manifestations of postoperative hyponatremia is unclear, but they may be due to effects of the actual irrigant used or, less commonly, to cerebral edema. In this patient, a noncontrast CT scan of the head may show cerebral edema but would not change management and could delay appropriate treatment. (Choice E) Although this patient received corticosteroids in the past, the lack of hypotension and of metabolic abnormalities consistent with adrenal insufficiency (eg, hyperkalemia, significant metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia) makes an adrenal crisis less likely. Educational objective: Postoperative hyponatremia usually occurs due to surgical stress-related release of vasopressin, use of nonelectrolyte solutions for irrigation, or infusion of hypotonic solutions. Acute, symptomatic hyponatremia should be emergently treated with hypertonic saline.

stem: A 73-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of acute onset of urinary incontinence after recent hospitalization for total knee replacement. Over the last 3 days, she has had 5-10 episodes of spontaneous urinary leakage daily. She also has had small, loose bowel movements. The patient has no urgency, increased frequency, dysuria, hematuria, or involuntary leakage associated with coughing, sneezing, or laughing. There is no recent history of fever or chills. Her other medical problems include hypertension, well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus with HbA1c of 6.9%, and chronic constipation. Her medications include metformin, glipizide, lisinopril, amlodipine, docusate, and oxycodone. She has not changed her diet or increased her caffeine intake. Her stable routine includes 1 or 2 alcoholic beverages each night. She has 4 children, all of whom were delivered vaginally. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is distended and mildly tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. Rectal examination shows hard stool in the rectal vault. Pelvic examination shows no thinning or pallor of the vaginal mucosa and no evidence of vaginal wall prolapse. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: A thorough history is essential to differentiate causes of urinary incontinence. Because many patients are very reluctant to initiate discussions about incontinence, all women age > 65 should be screened for voiding problems. History should evaluate factors such as duration, severity, triggering factors (eg, cough, sneeze), associations (eg, frequency, urgency, dysuria), obstetric and gynecologic history, lifestyle (eg, alcohol use), and medications. In addition to differentiating the type of urinary incontinence, the history may indicate reversible causes. This patient likely has incontinence related to potentially reversible conditions (transient incontinence). Her history and physical examination show stool impaction. Impaction can impair bladder emptying as bowel control shares the same sacral cord innervation as the bladder. Laxative treatment, such as polyethylene glycol to increase the water content of the stool, would likely improve both the constipation and urinary incontinence in this patient. (Choice A) Although urinary tract infections commonly cause incontinence in elderly patients, this patient's absence of infectious symptoms (eg, dysuria, hematuria) makes this less likely. A urinalysis is recommended as part of the initial workup. However, empiric treatment with antibiotics is not recommended. (Choice B) Estrogen cream can help atrophic vaginitis. However, this patient does not have findings (eg, vaginal mucosa pallor, vulvar erythema and inflammation) suggesting atrophic vaginitis. (Choice C) Oxybutynin is the most frequently prescribed antimuscarinic agent for urge incontinence or detrusor overactivity. However, this patient does not describe classic urge symptoms preceding her episodes of incontinence. (Choice D) Pelvic muscle exercises can help stress, urge, or mixed incontinence. However, this patient's absence of additional lower urinary tract symptoms (eg, worsening with cough) makes this less likely. Educational objective: Women age > 65 should undergo screening for voiding problems with a thorough history and physical examination. Incontinence related to potentially reversible conditions (transient incontinence) can be due to etiologies such as stool impaction, medications, urinary tract infection, mobility issues, lifestyle, and atrophic vaginitis.

stem: A 37-year-old woman is evaluated for generalized weakness. She has been hospitalized twice over the last year with similar complaints and her serum potassium concentration was found to be <3.0~mEq/L Her potassium concentration returned to normal with aggressive potassium replacement. She eats a normal diet and denies vomiting, purging, and cathartic or diuretic use. Her blood pressure is within normal limits. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Her sister suffers from Crohn's disease and her mother has congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and bipolar disorder. Her blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg and her pulse is 90/min. Her BMI is 22~kg/m^{2} Physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies are shown below: Complete blood count: Hemoglobin 12.8~g/dL, Hematocrit 38%. Serum chemistry: Sodium 136~mEq/L, Potassium 3.1~mEq/L, Chloride 90~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 30~mEq/L, Creatinine 0.8~mg/dL, Glucose 100~mg/dL. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.010, Protein none, Blood negative, Ketones negative, Nitrites negative, White blood cells 1-2/hpf, Red blood cells 1-2/hpf. Spot urinary chloride concentrations on two separate occasions were 15 and 65~mEq/L. Which of the following is most likely to establish diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient presents with unexplained hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The most common causes are vomiting/purging and diuretic use. Surreptitious vomiting or purging can be difficult to diagnose, but it usually presents with significant metabolic alkalosis and a low urinary chloride. This patient also lacks signs of self-induced vomiting such as ulcers on the dorsum of the hand, dental erosions from chronic acid exposure, or puffy cheeks from hypertrophied salivary glands. Diuretics cause a high urine chloride and metabolic alkalosis, but the urine chloride returns to low levels once the drug's effect wears off. As a result, surreptitious diuretic use is often associated with intermittent hypokalemia and variable urinary chloride excretion. In patients without physical signs of self-induced vomiting, a positive urinary screen for diuretics (usually on several occasions) is required to confirm the diagnosis of diuretic abuse. (Choice A) CT angiography of the renal arteries diagnoses renal artery stenosis and fibromuscular dysplasia, which both cause hypertension usually with a urine chloride > 40 mEq/L. This patient's normal blood pressure and variable urinary chloride make this less likely. (Choice B) Colonoscopy would be indicated for gastrointestinal causes of hypokalemia (e.g., diarrhea, surreptitious cathartic use, or a secretory villous adenomas), but those patients usually have metabolic acidosis from bicarbonate loss rather than alkalosis. (Choice C) Elevated plasma aldosterone with suppressed renin suggests hyperaldosteronism, which usually presents with persistent hypokalemia and hypertension. This patient's normal blood pressure and episodic hypokalemia make this less likely. (Choice D) Elevated C-peptide and insulin levels would suggest exogenous oral hypoglycemic agent abuse or insulinoma. Elevated insulin levels with low C-peptide levels suggest exogenous insulin abuse. However, this patient's lack of hypoglycemia makes this less likely. Educational objective: Intermittent hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis in the absence of vomiting suggests a diagnosis of either surreptitious purging or diuretic use. A variable urinary chloride favors diuretic abuse and can be confirmed with a urinary screen for diuretics.

stem: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office due to recurrent dysuria. She also has had dull pain in her right flank and cloudy urine that contains blood. The patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections since becoming sexually active in high school. Over the last year, she has had 3 infections accompanied by fever. Her last urine culture grew Klebsiella pneumoniae. The patient is in a monogamous relationship. For contraception, she uses a diaphragm or her partner uses a condom, both with spermicidal coatings. Temperature is 38.1 C (100.6 F), blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 95/min. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Mild right costovertebral angle tenderness is present on percussion. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 34%, Leukocytes 13,000/mm3, Sodium 140 mEq/L, Potassium 4.2 mEq/L, Chloride 102 mEq/L, Bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, Creatinine 1.9 mg/dL, Uric acid 8 mg/dL. Urinalysis: Specific gravity 1.013, PH 8, Protein none, Blood moderate, Glucose negative, Leukocyte esterase positive, Nitrites positive, Bacteria many, White blood cells 20-30/hpf, Red blood cells 20-30/hpf.
explanation: This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with a struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stone. These stones form only in the presence of an upper urinary tract infection with a urease-producing bacterium such as Proteus or Klebsiella. Urease cleaves urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide; the resulting ammonia then buffers hydrogen ions to form ammonium, which increases the urinary pH to >7. The alkaline environment promotes the precipitation of magnesium ammonium phosphate, leading to the formation of large staghorn calculi. These stones can provide a nidus for recurrent infection. Treatment requires complete removal of the stone (usually via percutaneous nephrolithotomy) in addition to antibiotic therapy to eradicate the infection and prevent recurrence.
